TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, will be absent from the chamber today. Senator Richardson is ill. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Richardson in relation to his portfolio should be directed to Senator Tate and questions in relation to those portfolios he represents should be directed to Senator Collins.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Will the Government intervene and support the application by the Australian Manufacturers Council on behalf of SPC Ltd and its employees to obtain a variation of their award in order to give effect to the agreement entered into between SPC and its employees in order to preserve the jobs in the factory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I congratulate SPC and the Victorian Trades Hall unions for at last meeting last week and talking about the terms of the agreement. I am disappointed that out of those talks no agreement emerged. I believe that the right course has now been taken in having the matter referred to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to determine what should occur. I indicate that I am thinking of making later this week a more general statement of what principle should apply in situations like this, but note for the interest of honourable senators that there appears in the Age and the Australian Financial Review today two analytical articles which cast interesting light on this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand also that SPC will be in this building on Thursday and will talk with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, on matters of protection. The SPC has not sought a meeting with me on industrial relations issues, but I will seek a meeting with it because I think there are a number of matters about this issue that I would like to have clarified for myself.

At micro level this may well in microcosm represent what is in macrocosm a bit of a problem in the general economy. That is, in 1985, 1986, 1987 and 1988 the economy was growing strongly; through the accord, wages were moderated with low wage outcomes and a distribution in factor shares away from wages to profits. Workers exercised commendable restraint, but the trouble was that those profits were used by speculators in unprecedented speculation activity and they lost the money. Workers are now being asked to find a way to generate more investment capital by further helping to restrain wages and distributing factor shares to profits. In microcosm that is what appears to be the case with this company. It appears to have made a number of bad investment decisions-it is now debt ridden; that is what the shareholders say-and consequently it needs to find a way around the problem.

The existing system is flexible enough to deal with matters of this sort. The company could seek a section 115 agreement direct with its work force, as a number of significant Australian companies have done. Without trying to play favourites, I give but one example where companies across the board have sought this flexibility provision. ICI Australia Ltd at Botany has reached a section 115 agreement with its work force because of the peculiar situation with which that company was faced and the competitive market in which it competed. It achieved significant flexibility in its own operation, major savings and in fact a more competitive output. That is one course.

Award modernisation and flexibility is another course that could have been taken. A capacity to pay argument could have been raised. I would like to know from SPC why it did not choose any of those courses or consult with its unions in the beginning. The terms of a number of other arrangements have not been communicated to the Government by the company-arrangements which are essential to the Government making a reasoned and proper decision in this case, as it will.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was all of this revealed at the time of Hewson's stunt up there?

—My Leader, Senator Button, interjects as to whether this has all come to hand in the time of Dr Hewson's stunt. Some of it was known before Dr Hewson decided to turn what is an industrial relations and economic issue into a political cavalcade and comedy. My advice to Dr Hewson is to butt out and leave the parties to industrial relations and the umpire to determine this matter. This is not a matter for political circuses; this is a matter for sober decision making. The system is flexible enough, and the flexibility of the system should be allowed.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. We have had a lot of words from Senator Cook. I would like to point out that there was no stunt on the part of Dr Hewson. He is simply giving effect to what has been Opposition policy now for over four years. I ask the Minister: seeing that this is an important matter, why is the Government not intervening now, as the case is in the Industrial Relations Commission and could be heard quite quickly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my answer I made clear at least this point: the Government has received no approach from the company about this matter at all. So we have had no request to us from the company to intervene. From the union side, we have had no request to intervene, either. In terms of my independent advice, there are a number of issues and questions, some of which I have referred to in my answer, to which I would like to know the answer before the Government could form an attitude. Let me say that the system is flexible for companies which wish, in straitened economic times, to make particular deals with their work force to do so, but within the system so that the umpire can say that those deals are fair. That is the proper course for companies to take.

ANSWER.PARA: In this case, the company did not take that approach initially and there are a number of elements, which I referred to, that are still not clear. For example, the company has said that it will introduce a profit sharing scheme should it return to economic viability in the future, although it has not said what the profit sharing scheme will be. There is another question about the role of part time workers in this decision made by the work force of the company. There have been allegations that the permanent work force made a decision on behalf of the part time work force. I do not judge those allegations, but they are matters upon which the Government needs advice before it can make a decision on this matter.

Finally, there is another matter. The company has retained International Public Relations Pty Ltd (IPR), a major public relations company in Australia, at considerable cost. I am not sure whether the workers, when they voted in their ballot, knew that there would be a retainer for a company such as this at considerable cost. One asks why a company like IPR, with New Right associations, should be engaged in an industrial matter like this when the course of going to the Commission was always open to the company.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RETURN OF NAVAL VESSELS FROM MIDDLE EAST DUTY

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Defence: what arrangements, if any, have been made to welcome the return of the ships HMAS Darwin and HMAS Adelaide to their home port of Sydney this week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to inform the Senate that our ships were well received when they made their first Australian landfall at the Port of Darwin last Friday where they were welcomed by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Bilney, on behalf of the Government. This Friday is particularly significant as it will see the return of the ships to their home port of Sydney. ANSWER.PARA: While it is not possible to open the fleet base to the Sydney public, I invite any members of the public who are interested to assemble at suitable vantage points around the harbour to view the procession and give our ships a rousing welcome. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. When the Government was engineering the recession, did it take into account today's tax deadline in assessing the economic stress to business? Has the Government assessed the number of business bankruptcies likely to result from today's tax requirements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of suppositions behind Senator Walters's question which I do not want to deal with. But let me try and get a few facts straight on the record in relation to this matter, because the facts have not been there in some of the public comment on this issue. As I said in the Senate last week, the Government's decision in the 1989-90 Budget to alter the timing of company tax payments was made against the background that the majority of businesses are not conducted as companies. For example, only some 25 per cent of small businesses are incorporated, and in the papers comment has been largely about small businesses. The majority of those businesses-75 per cent of small businesses, for example-are subject to provisional tax arrangements. The former company tax collection arrangement offered those businesses operating as companies a substantial advantage in terms of the timing of tax payments over those which were paying provisional tax. That was an inequity in the system which the Government sought to deal with at the time the legislation was introduced.

ANSWER.PARA: The new measures seek to reduce but do not remove the deferral benefit associated with the previous quarterly system; that is, there is still an advantage to those incorporated companies over those companies that are not incorporated and which are paying provisional tax. The 1989-90 Budget measure, as announced, would have required all June balancing companies with notional tax liabilities in excess of $1,000 to have paid 85 per cent of notional or estimated tax in July this year, with the final payment by March next year. However, to ease the impact of the transition to the new measures, the Government decided to allow companies with notional or estimated tax liabilities under $400,000-that is, the smaller business end of the spectrum-in this current financial year the option of paying their total liability in December.

This arrangement still, of course, results in an element of bring forward in the timing of payments vis-a-vis the former quarterly payment system, but not to the extent of the original announcement. Any deferral in the timing of payments until February or March could result in a tax deferral gain to taxpayers beyond that of the former quarterly system. It should be borne in mind that the tax payments due today are in respect of profits earned in the year ended 30 June 1990-that is six months ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —There won't be too many of them, will there?

—Senator Crichton-Browne is always quick with the gun but I do not think he shot anything with that one. Perhaps he is anticipating next year's company profits. Furthermore, those companies which operate on a substituted accounting basis and closed their books between December 1989 and May 1990 in lieu of June 1990 would already have met their tax obligations for the 1989-90 income year and the deferral for June-balancing companies would discriminate against many companies which have already paid their obligation in respect of this tax period.
—You are not answering the question at all.

—Well, it may not be an answer that the honourable senator likes or even an answer that she can follow. But fortunately we have a thing called the Senate Hansard which will recall this answer. I hope that the Senate pinks will record this answer faithfully because these facts ought to be put on the record. To that extent, for the first time in my life I am grateful to the honourable senator.

ANSWER.PARA: In summary, the Government will not be granting a further general extension of the arrangements. However, where companies are facing genuine financial hardship as a result of the need to meet the current payment, they should contact their local taxation office regarding their particular circumstance with a view to discussing a mutually agreeable time frame for payment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that because only 25 per cent of small businesses would be affected by today's tax deadline, it does not matter how many bankruptcies there will be? Surely-and I have already asked this question-the Government must have assessed the number of business bankruptcies likely to result from today's deadlines.

—I did say that some 25 per cent of companies were incorporated. After that, I suppose the honourable senator's attention span disappeared. I said a lot of other things as well. What I suggest is that she sit down and read the Hansard in terms of what I said. Hopefully she will then understand the answer. If she cannot follow the answer, she should not ask supplementary questions.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister seen press reports this morning that the Hun Sen Government in Cambodia and Vietnam have criticised the United Nations (UN) peace plan for Cambodia? What is the Government's assessment of this development and the current prospects for achieving a comprehensive peace settlement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of press reports, including in today's Age, that Hun Sen's State of Cambodia (SOC) regime in Phnom Penh and Vietnam have hardened their position towards the comprehensive settlement plan initiated by Australia and subsequently, of course, adopted by the United Nations.

ANSWER.PARA: The SOC's sensitivities-that is to say, the Phnom Penh Government's sensitivities-about the proposed United Nations administrative and military role in the transitional period have been known for some time and do not necessarily of themselves denote any kind of hardening of the SOC position. It has been reported that at a press conference for foreign correspondents in Phnom Penh as recently as a couple of weeks ago, on 29 November, Hun Sen in fact reiterated the SOC's acceptance of the Permanent Five (P5) framework document.

I think it is important to note, as we watch the ebb and flow of rhetoric in the last stages, hopefully, of the settlement process, that the P5 framework, accepted in its entirety by all Cambodian parties as the basis for settling the Cambodian conflict, does not envisage the dismantling of the SOC regime. Rather, it provides for the exercise of such control by the United Nations transitional authority in Cambodia as is necessary to ensure the strict neutrality of administrative agencies, bodies and officers which could directly influence the outcome of the elections.

Quite a lot of the reporting that one sees is addressed to the bogy of dismantling the Phnom Penh Government. I make the point again for the record that the full dismantling of that Government is not what is in any way proposed by the UN peace plan. So far as Vietnam is concerned, its concerns are also not new and their reiteration does not of itself signify any hardening of its position.

Mr President, a most welcome development in the settlement process has been the decision announced just in the last couple of days of the co-Chairmen of the Paris Conference, Indonesia and France, to meet members of the Supreme National Council (SNC) in Paris later this week. Hun Sen has already indicated publicly that he will attend that meeting; the other factions had indicated some time earlier.

The purpose of the meeting is to brief the SNC members on the draft settlement text and to discuss with them the functioning of the SNC. We do all hope that, arising from that, some major progress will be made, in particular so as to enable reconvening of the coordination committee of the Paris conference in January next year. Australia is maintaining very close contact with key players in the negotiating process. We expect to play an active role in that Paris conference context when the committee and the conference itself are reconvened.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Has the Minister noted that the Victorian Government has recently enacted an Industrial Waste Management Policy (Waste Minimisation) Act? In relation to waste of energy, is it a fact that Australia is the only Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) country that has not set national standards for energy efficiency in buildings? When will this Government introduce legislation setting national standards for energy efficiency in buildings? When will the Government introduce legislation to phase out the production of intractable chemical wastes by 1 January 1996, in accordance with an agreement reached at an Australian and New Zealand Environment Council meeting in July this year, and consistent with a recommendation of the joint task force on intractable waste?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am obliged to Senator Coulter for prior notice of this question. The Minister has provided me with the following information. Yes, the Minister is aware of the recent Victorian legislation and will be examining it closely during the preparation of the national waste minimisation recycling strategy. Yes, the Federal Government is concerned that it is possible to construct buildings in Australia without due regard to energy efficiency, perhaps because of our mild climate relative to that of other OECD countries. Australia has not yet implemented many of the potential energy saving improvements which many other OECD countries have. Happily, this means that there is a great potential to do so. As a result--

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Tate interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I thought that was cute, too. As a result of the Government's decision to have a planning target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, the Government endorsed an energy management program initiative package to be implemented by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. As part of that package, in February next year every household in Australia will be provided with an information kit on ways to cut down our domestic energy consumption. Access to information is the first important step in implementing the wide community commitment to reducing our contribution to the greenhouse effect. As the responsibility for energy and building standards falls within the portfolios of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, and ultimately the States and Territories, the Minister will seek the advice of her colleagues Senator Button and Mr Kerin and get back to Senator Coulter as soon as possible with an answer on the Government's intention in relation to national standards in this area.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of legislation designed to minimise the production of industrial waste, as I said, the Government is developing a national waste minimisation and recycling strategy in consultation with State governments. This will address the options for government action, including the option of legislation for the minimisation and control of both industrial and domestic waste. The draft strategy will be available early next year for public comment. The Government remains committed to introducing legislation to phase out the production of intractable waste by 1 January 1996. The Minister is not aware of the precise timing for the introduction of that legislation to Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and it relates to the SPC Ltd agreement. In view of the widespread public support for the agreement, evidenced by the Morgan gallup poll finding that 88 per cent of the community, including 75 per cent of Labor voters, support the deal as necessary, will the Government amend the Industrial Relations Act to enable these agreements to take effect with the wishes of both parties instead of being subject to approval by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports of the Morgan gallup poll but I have not seen the poll. I note the response to it which is, as the question implies, overwhelming, but I do not know what the question was and how the questions were framed, so I make no judgment about the veracity of the poll. When I obtain a copy of it and see the results, I will make a judgment about it. However, I must say that I am not surprised at the level of support, given the publicity that has attended this type of deal in Shepparton.

ANSWER.PARA: Will we amend the Act? I have made it clear that the Act provides for great flexibility for particular working arrangements. The first and most obvious example in this case is section 115 of the Act, which enables companies and employees to work out arrangements for wages and working conditions different from mainstream awards but suitable to the particular needs of a company and the trading environment that it operates in. A good example of that is the ICI Botany agreement in which sick leave has been given over in favour of an honour system and a number of other changes have been made which have put that company on a competitive footing. I point out that this has been done consensually: it has been done by agreement between the unions, the workers and the company concerned, and registered in the Commission.

I secondly point out that under the award modification provisions provided for in the last national wage case decision there is provision, in the case of particular awards-and this award as regards food preservers has this flexibility provision-for award flexibility to take advantage of particular circumstances with a particular respondent, as this case would be.

I thirdly point out that there is a provision under the Act to mount a capacity to pay argument. There are principles laid down on how that should be conducted and that is there nonetheless where incapacity to pay besets a particular employer. All of these things are provisions within the Act or within benchmark decisions like national wage case decisions governing wage fixation.

I fourthly point out that under the award restructuring provisions the emphasis is now on workplace change, with a workplace change being designed to generate greater productivity or profitability in the workplace. But the significant thing about all of these provisions is that they should be taken to the Industrial Relations Commission. Why should they be taken to the Industrial Relations Commission? Clearly, the umpire needs to see that each of these deals is fair and that we do not find a situation in which, with a higher level of unemployment than this Government likes to see and with the bargaining share switching from workers to companies, people are particularly taken advantage of or victimised in any particular circumstance. That is why the umpire should scrutinise each of these arrangements. Given the flexibility I have referred to, there is no reason to amend the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, Mr President. The three instances that the Minister mentioned all involve going to the Commission. Am I to take it from the Minister's answer that he feels that there is a need for the Commission to be involved in order to impose fairness in certain circumstances where workers might have misunderstood what was in their best interests? Does it follow from that, if we are satisfied and the community is satisfied that the SPC workers are taking a deal that would be necessary to enable the company to survive, that somehow the Commission ought to have the power to overturn the arrangements and in the interests of fairness put them out of work?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commission makes a judgment based on the principles of justice, equity and the substantial merits of each case. This Commission exists for the purposes of regulating industrial relations in Australia. When there is a problem with industrial relations or the standards imposed by the Commission, then the Commission is the right place to go and settle it. When one moves outside the Commission and tries to act against the prevailing method of doing things there are problems.

ANSWER.PARA: The issue of SPC started off outside; it is now coming back inside. As I have said, that is a welcome change. Senator Alston throws up as an example one set of circumstances that may obtain. I will throw up another example in reply, if he will just give me a chance to do so. In a time of high unemployment it is not unknown in industry for some employers to say to workers, `You will accept these reduced provisions or you will be sacked'. In that situation there is no fairness and no bargaining opportunity. The reason why an umpire needs to be in place to scrutinise those types of deals is to see that there is fairness.

Another observation I make about the proposition which Senator Alston has put is that it assumes fundamentally that unions covering workers in this country are not concerned about unemployment. I have had speeches delivered to me by leaders of particular unions and officers of the Australian Council of Trade Unions about unemployment. They are concerned about unemployment and about being flexible having regard to the circumstances of particular companies to make the relevant arrangements. One does not obtain cooperation by ignoring and going around them when they are part of the industrial relations institutions in this country. The proper arrangements are made by working with and through them so that better arrangements are made.

I conclude by saying that this country has come a long way since the days when the Liberal Party was in government. We have come a huge distance- a million miles-in industrial relations from the type of New Right philosophies the Opposition has expounded. We have come through a period of massive award restructuring which has underpinned industrial efficiencies in this country which otherwise would not have been able to be achieved; we have come through a period of high economic growth when the bargaining shares were reviewed--

TALK.START.PARA: —For whom? Halfpenny?
—Order!

—In those circumstances we found moderate wage outcomes. At present the level of industrial disputes are running down and are now trending off the bottom of the graph, unlike the Fraser era when Australian was put against Australian.
—Order! Senator Cook, you are debating the question.
—Why don't you pull them up?
—Order!

—Thank you, Mr President. By contrast, we can sort these problems out by working within the system and with the institutions in the system. If those opposite wish to confront them and have a blue, that is what they will get. In these circumstances, I preach that there be some moderation and proper consultation and that we resolve the problem as a country or an industry, not through confrontation and division, which the Opposition preaches.

—Can the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support advise the Senate on the role to be played by the OTC Maritime Communications station, Melbourne radio, in Australia's new maritime radio communications distress and safety system?

—I have advised the Senate on previous occasions about the success of the new satellite technology that assists mariners in distress at sea. I have also given previous commitments publicly that I would continue to ensure that the data provided for the existing high frequency services that OTC has provided is continually under review. That review has revealed a situation where OTC has revised downwards the data it provided on the efficiency of its antennas. As a result, I have made a decision that the Melbourne OTC high frequency radio will continue to operate as part of that system. This will be of some interest to senators on both Government and Opposition benches who have made representations to me in relation to southern areas of Australia, including the waters of Tasmania. As a result of the decision that I have taken on this matter, erring as is always done in these cases on the side of caution, the OTC network which will remain in place will now be stationed in Perth, Melbourne, Sydney, Townsville and Darwin.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the truckload of leaked documents on Cambodia referred to in today's press, including confidential views of the United States and British governments. Does the Minister know the source of the leaks, and has this matter been referred to the Australian Federal Police? What has been the result of the AFP investigations of the 16 previous serious leaks since June which the Opposition raised in Estimates committees, and why is it that Australian national interests are being undermined from within the Foreign Affairs Department?

—It is a matter of very considerable concern when unauthorised disclosures, particularly on the scale we have witnessed some weeks ago and now again over the weekend, do occur. It is the case that the Australian Federal Police have been asked to add these latest disclosures to their investigations. I have made it very clear to all officers of my Department that I take a very serious view of breaches of security. I am not in a position at this stage to report in any detail on the outcome of the earlier investigations by the police, which are still proceeding, to the best of my knowledge.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Have the latest leaks been referred to the Australian Federal Police, and has the Australian Government apologised to the British and United States governments for the embarrassment caused?

—I have just said that the Australian Federal Police have been asked to add these latest disclosures to their investigations. I said that a moment ago. I do not think the question of any apology arises.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce been drawn to an article in the Australian Financial Review of 12 November entitled, `Money to be made out of muck', in which it was claimed that there is significant potential for the export of Australian waste management technologies? Can the Minister inform the Senate what initiatives have been taken by the Government in encouraging Australian companies to develop waste management technologies and capitalise on their export potential?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important question. Some European companies estimate that something like one-third of their business in the 1990s will be devoted to environmental engineering and waste management problems. There are significant national and international opportunities for Australian companies working in these fields. The environment management industry, as it is called, covers a range of technologies, products and systems which are designed to assist in the preservation or restoration of the environment. Australia has some particular strengths in liquid waste treatment, membrane technology, bioremediation and sensing equipment.

ANSWER.PARA: The broad range of technologies has of course, not unusually in Australia, in the past led to a fragmented industry. My Department has been encouraging the development of a common purpose within the industry through support for the establishment of an environmental management industry association. The companies involved are also forming an export group, with the assistance of Austrade. The Government is also assisting information flows within the industry, and a recent publication on waste management technologies and so on has been well received in the industry. In recognition of the growth potential for industries of this kind, a system was established within the generic grants scheme to make particular research and development grants to projects relating to the industry. Environmental management and technologies is also one of the priority fields being considered in the multifunction polis feasibility study.

The area of environmental management is in some ways a relatively high technology industry now, as distinct from the past. There are some very interesting Australian companies, such as Memtec Ltd, the Sydney company which specialises in membrane filtration, and a company in Brisbane called Neutralysis, which is a small company at this stage but which has some undoubted interest being shown in its processes in the United States and elsewhere. There are other companies of that kind which I think are well positioned to grow with the importance of the waste management industry in the future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, relates to the Ambassador to Ireland, Brian Burke. I remind the Minister that he said:

QUESTION.PARA: If and when evidence emerges through the courts or elsewhere which could make it inappropriate for the ambassadorial position to be maintained then I will act.

I ask the Minister: when will he act, when he has failed to act in relation to Burke's misleading of the McCusker inquiry, his misleading of the National Companies and Securities Commission and his involvement in the monitoring of Opposition politicians? I ask the Minister whether he agrees with the Sydney Morning Herald editorial of 6 December last that stated:
Senator Evans, to protect the credibility of the ambassadorial system should act now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell, like most of his colleagues, does not seem to understand the difference between allegation and evidence. I am not in the business of responding to allegations, and I would hope that those opposite who shed such floods of crocodile tears on these occasions would accept a bit more widely and consistently the principle of assumption of innocence unless the contrary is proven. There is no basis whatsoever, in terms of the material available to me, to make any such assumption in this case, and my answers on previous occasions stand accordingly.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps the Minister could advise the Senate as to where else he may find it inappropriate, if evidence which may come before him does not emerge through the courts.

—There is a difference, which again Senator Campbell does not seem to appreciate, between a court and a royal commission. It may well be in the context of a royal commission that something could arise which would have evidentiary status of the kind I am talking about. I make no assumption, of course, that any such material will emerge, but I stand ready to evaluate anything that should arise, on its merits. I am not going to jump in to any premature response of the kind that Senator Campbell is inviting me to make. It would be wholly inappropriate and inconsistent with my obligations to respect the standing of individuals of stature within the community and not to make assumptions about them, were I to do otherwise. That is the basis on which I express my continuing confidence in the Ambassador to Ireland.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Considering Minister Kerin's rejection of a price stabilisation suggestion from Australia's citrus industry, considering Australia's imports of fruit juice, dried fruits, processed fruits and other horticultural products, and considering that four million litres of unsold wine was dumped at Griffith this weekend, does the Minister recognise that the Government is supervising a deepening rural recession affecting not only Australia's farmers but also process workers and transporters? What level of need has to occur before the Government will intervene? How many farmers need to leave their farms? How many rural families have to suffer before this Government recognises their need for support? What urgent, immediate steps will the Minister now undertake to help alleviate the crisis which affects all Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bell will recognise that once more he has made a shameless play for a headline in Tasmania rather than concentrate--
—It is not just Tasmania. This is a situation affecting every State in Australia.

—Maybe he has made a shameless play for headlines all around Australia, in that case, rather than concentrate on the issues of international trade with which this Government has been concerned. I do not need to reiterate in this chamber that this Government has been concerned to argue in this most recent General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) round that world trade should be free, and that if it were Australia would have a greater chance for major agricultural exports to penetrate markets in North America and Europe, and more particularly the markets that are traded to by Europe and North America in our general trading zone, and that it is in the interests of this country to achieve that type of breakthrough.

ANSWER.PARA: What Senator Bell is referring to is that in particular industries we should provide specific protection or specific subsidy to make trade unequal-justifying, in the face of what we have seen in the last few weeks at GATT, some form of retaliation against Australia for its subsidies and unequal treatment of trade matters. In an intense world trading climate, that would work to the absolute detriment of this country. If that is what Senator Bell is preaching, let us get the context right. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the previous question based on the facts as they are occurring now and the observation that the type of breakthrough to free trade which is proposed by the Government has not worked. What is the Government going to do?

Given the recent revelations that the present Ambassador to Ireland, Mr Brian Burke, has, in association with disgraced former private detective, Robert Smith; his brother, the then Secretary to Cabinet, Terry Burke; and his then chauffeur, Vince Shervington, been associated with the acquisition and distribution of information covertly acquired about political opponents, will the Minister obtain an undertaking from the Ambassador that he has not conducted himself in an improper or illegal way and that his conduct has not been inconsistent with standards expected of Australian ambassadors?
—I have nothing to add to my previous answers on that subject.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to reports over the weekend of a breakdown in negotiations between the United States of America and Iraq on possible high level discussions aimed at a peaceful resolution of the Gulf crisis. In that light, what is the Australian Government's assessment of this development and the climate for future contact and discussions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is too early to make any assumption that the prospect of high level talks between the United States and Iraq has now evaporated. Although the visits of Iraqi Foreign Minister Tareq Aziz to Washington and United States Secretary of State James Baker to Iraq are both on hold as a result of the failure to agree on dates and following an obvious stalling exercise from the Iraqi side, I think it is reasonable to hope that some new dates will emerge over the next few days. Since there can be no doubt at all about the determination of the coalition to bring matters to a head forcefully if United Nations (UN) objectives cannot be achieved in any other way, the objective fact of the matter is that there is much more for Saddam Hussein to lose than to gain if the talks fall through completely.

ANSWER.PARA: The basic objective of the proposed discussions, as Secretary Baker has made very clear, is to make absolutely clear to Iraq the nature of the forces arrayed against it and the absolute necessity of its complying with UN resolutions. Consistent with that, there is no reason in Australia's view why some other matters could not usefully and constructively be discussed-in particular, the future shape of security arrangements in the Gulf region and perhaps also the means of resolving some of the matters originally in bilateral dispute between Iraq and Kuwait.

What cannot and will not be linked to discussions about the Gulf conflict is the question of the resolution of the Palestinian and other outstanding Middle Eastern issues. While, as President Bush and Secretary Baker have said, the resolution of the Gulf crisis may well constitute an `opportunity' or a `springboard' to address these issues, they are separate and distinct and must remain so. It is, accordingly, simply chasing a will-o'-the-wisp for Iraq to insist that the Palestinian and other Middle East issues must be on the agenda of the talks. It is simply part of Iraq's continuing attempt to divert attention from and confuse the issue of its aggression against Kuwait and, as such, must be dismissed out of hand.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LABELLING OF PRODUCTS TO SHOW ORIGIN

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I remind the Minister of his statement in the Senate, in answer to Senator Boswell's questions on labelling, when he gave a commitment that the labels on fruit juices were to show the country of origin for all imported ingredients. Is the Minister aware that the draft report of the Australian Food Standards Committee recommends that fruit juices and fruit juice products must carry on their labels a statement of the country of origin of the imported fruit components or a statement to the effect that part or all of the ingredients are imported? Does the Minister agree that a statement on the label that a product is imported is totally unsatisfactory and will he ensure that his own commitment for country of origin of all ingredients will be clearly shown on the label? Will the Minister also give a similar assurance that labelling of flower arrangements will show country of origin for any imported flowers or foliage included in the arrangement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have taken a very strong stand that, by unleashing consumer power in the marketplace, there is no doubt that Australians can help those of their fellow Australians in the farming industry, in orchards and in the fishing industry by ensuring that, when they have presented to them a variety of foodstuffs, they can make a choice which favours the Australian produce. I believe that they can be aided in that particular task by clear labelling of the country of origin of imported foodstuffs. I am aware of the recommendation of the Australian Food Standards Committee made in Perth a couple of weeks ago and I believe that it is imperative that the country of origin be shown, because I believe that that is an important indication to consumers of the country of origin and, therefore, of the choice that they are confronting. One hopes that they will then favour the Australian produce.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the exact wording on the label, that is a matter which comes before the various health Ministers of Australia. In view of the unfortunate fragmentation of responsibility in our Federation and between different portfolios, that should be the case. I have written to the various health Ministers in all the jurisdictions of Australia encouraging them to move very quickly on the recommendations. I will certainly take up Senator Bjelke-Petersen's admonition that one needs to have a clearer statement of the country of origin rather than simply a statement that imported ingredients are used in the preparation and sale of certain fruit juices.

I believe that if Australian consumers were confronted with the information that a particular fruit juice did contain imported ingredients, knowing as we do that in some instances fruit juice concentrate is merely diluted with Australian water before it is peddled on the Australian market as produce of Australia, that would be sufficient to give pause and enable them to make a choice in favour of the Australian product.

I have no knowledge of a proposal that floral arrangements be labelled in any particular way. I will take that matter up. However, I do not believe that it is a matter of such concern as, for example, the one that led me a week or so ago to speak about the labelling of unpackaged vegetables, fruit, fish and nut products because in those areas there is obviously an imperative need and that will be met.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the lack of fluency in English emerging as a significant factor inhibiting the benefits of award restructuring being realised in the workplace? Is the Government aware of the program being run by Nissan Australia in dealing with problems of literacy and numeracy in its work force, and does the Minister believe that this could be a model for other companies facing similar difficulties? What action is the Government taking to resolve these problems?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government and Nissan Australia have released a video entitled What's in it for us?, which is available in English and Vietnamese. Later it will come out in other languages that are spoken by the Australian work force. The video explains how award restructuring operates and the advantages both to workers and employers in a workplace of engaging in restructuring the productive output of that workplace. The Government has paid $30,000 towards the production of that video. The total cost has been made up by services provided by management and workers at Nissan Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the big advantages of the accord is that it has introduced a major change in terms of award restructuring; quite astonishing change has occurred. It is now supported by all the parties. The Confederation of Australian Industry strongly argued for it in national wage case proceedings and it made that point again this year.

Award restructuring means that we break down the old craft and trade classifications and have multiskilled trade persons. We make the work force more flexible so that it is better able to adapt to and deal with new technology. It introduces career paths into awards so that workers do not remain locked forever in the job classification that they start out in and it provides advancement by training and qualifications. The wages system is used as an incentive in this. It provides a setting to agree on how to remove inefficiencies and generate greater productivity and profitability and how that productivity and profitability should best be shared. Those are the advantages of award restructuring.

One of the problems in the manufacturing industry in proceeding with it is that we have uncovered a lack of numeracy and literacy skills in the ordinary industrial work force. It is estimated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions that poor English fluency in the workplace costs $6.5 billion a year in terms of lost productivity and between $10m and $13m in terms of workers compensation. It is estimated that Australia has one million workers in need of training in this area. So the Commonwealth Government, in supporting the actions being taken by employers, workers and unions, has proceeded to present this video.
Mr Ivan Deveson of Nissan Australia is reported as having said:

Award restructuring paid higher dividends to companies that implemented it properly, but language was a hurdle that had to be cleared first. . . But one of the largest problems confronting award restructuring was that of illiteracy . . . The problem of communicating, because of the weaknesses in our English language, are horrendous . . . We underestimated that. The literacy and numeracy problems of our country, which may or may not be typified by the Nissan workforce, are horrendous. In Nissan's body shop, employees came from 77 ethnic groups and spoke 27 different languages. Although the language of the company is English, we have to handle that challenge.

He went on to demonstrate how his company has benefited massively from award restructuring and how that enables weaknesses in achieving a more flexible work force to be identified. This is one that has been, and the Federal Government is pleased to join with Nissan in trying to address that problem on its behalf and in its workplace as well as on behalf of other major manufacturing enterprises in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and follows answers he has given previously on the SPC issue. In noting that the Minister congratulated the employer and the Victorian Trades Hall Council over that matter, I ask him whether he also supports the efforts taken by the workers to protect their jobs. I stand four square and true behind that statement, and we will not resile from that. —I have a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister did not answer the question. I think he said that he was sort of supporting the workers providing they did what their union bosses said, but the second half of the question asked whether he was also supporting the Victorian Government's assessment of Mr Halfpenny's contribution.

—Firstly, I do not accept Senator Hill's attempt to pervert my words. If he wants to go back to the record he will see exactly what I said. I do not need his assistance in interpreting what I said, in this chamber or anywhere else-thank you, Senator Hill! In terms of the Victorian Trades Hall Council, John Halfpenny may well not be a popular figure. I acknowledge that. —I have a supplementary answer to a question asked of me on 12 December by Senator McMullan about human rights in Vietnam and about the Most Venerable Thich Quang Do and the Most Venerable Thich Nhuen Quang. In my response I said that the most recent report from the Australian Embassy in Hanoi dated July 1989 advised that both had been released and were now freely practising their religion in the Nghia Binh and Thai Binh provinces respectively. It has been brought to my attention that since the release of this report from the Australian Embassy in Hanoi, the Amnesty International report entitled Vietnam, Renovation (Doi Moi) the Law and Human Rights in the 1980s, published in February 1990, claims that the two monks are still under house arrest in their native villages. I have therefore instructed Australian Embassy staff in Hanoi to visit the two provinces in the course of their provincial travels to verify whether the two were indeed released as we were formally advised last year by the Vietnamese authorities. On a positive note, I can advise that on 10 December the Australian Embassy in Hanoi raised 11 other human rights cases with the Vietnamese foreign ministry and was advised that two of the 11 had already been released from detention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week Senator Teague asked me a question about Cambodia and Mr Costello's conversations in Beijing. I would like to make a supplementary answer to that in the light of Senator Teague's response to my invitation later that day to put down a document in the Senate bearing upon his question. I would like first to explain that since launching our initiative in November last year to revive the Cambodian peace process Australia has had a large number of private discussions with the various Cambodian parties and other relevant governments at both ministerial and senior official level. The value of our contribution to the peace process has depended crucially on our respecting the confidentiality of those discussions. Accordingly, I do not intend to undermine our credentials to play a continuing facilitating role in the peace process by divulging all the details of our various conversations with Prince Sihanouk and his son Prince Ranariddh, who is the executive leader of the Cambodian party FUNCINPEC.

ANSWER.PARA: However, because Senator Teague has chosen to ask specific questions about Mr Costello's meeting with Prince Sihanouk in Pyongyang on 2 November, let me simply say that I have now had a opportunity to check personally the relevant records and I can confirm the accuracy of the response I gave to Senator Teague's question without notice last week. Mr Costello has told me that when he met with Prince Sihanouk in Pyongyang he did not say anything to suggest that Australia was on the point of recognising the Hun Sen regime nor did he say anything to suggest that we believed a second Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia was likely. There is nothing in the detailed record of conversation prepared at the time to suggest otherwise.

On 13 December Senator Teague tabled a copy of the document which purports to be the translation of a message of 4 November from Prince Sihanouk to Prince Ranariddh, who was then in Bangkok, which makes reference to Mr Costello's conversation with Prince Sihanouk in Pyongyang on 2 November. I am able to say that Mr Costello met Prince Ranariddh in Bangkok on 6 November and found him to have received a version of a message containing some misunderstandings of Mr Costello's conversation four days earlier with Prince Sihanouk. Those misunderstandings related to issues similar to those raised last week by Senator Teague and were carefully corrected at the time by Mr Costello.

I would like to confirm for the record that Australia's relations with Prince Sihanouk are most cordial and constructive. We recognise the unique place he occupies in the affairs of his country. He has given firm support and encouragement to Australia's efforts to assist the international negotiating process aimed at a comprehensive settlement of the tragic Cambodian conflict. We, for one, have no doubt at all that he will continue to play a central, important and perhaps decisive role in the affairs of his country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans has sent me by letter today an answer to a question I asked on 4 December. I seek leave to incorporate the answer from the Minister in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
SENATOR THE HON. GARETH EVANS Q.C.
MINISTER FOR FOREIGN AFFAIRS
AND TRADE
PARLIAMENT HOUSE, CANBERRA A.C.T. 2600
17 DEC l990
Senator Baden Teague
Senator for South Australia
The Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Teague
In my response to your Question without Notice concerning Cambodia on 4 December I said that the issues you raised would be addressed in my Ministerial Statement of 6 December 1990.

There was one query concerning the responsibility of Son Sen for human rights violations that was not covered specifically in the Statement-although the relevant considerations were addressed in general terms on p.17 of the document as circulated-and I would like to respond further to that.

Son Sen is a senior Khmer Rouge leader and is currently the commander of the Khmer Rouge military forces (called the National Army of Democratic Kampuchea-NADK). Prior to the overthrow of the Khmer Rouge regime in December 1978 January 1979, Son Sen was Deputy Prime Minister in charge of defence. Together with Khieu Samphan, who is the nominal leader of the Khmer Rouge (President of the Party of Democratic Kampuchea), Son Sen was nominated by the Khmer Rouge to be a member of the Supreme National Council established by the Cambodian parties at their meeting in Jakarta on 9-10 September 1990. As confirmed in the joint statement issued at the conclusion of that meeting, Khieu Samphan's and Son Sen's membership of the SNC was in fact accepted by the SOC and the two other Cambodian parties. (There are ten other members of the SNC-six nominated by the SOC, two by FUNCINPEC (Prince Sihanouk's faction) and two by the KPNLF (Son Sann's faction)).

As a senior figure of the Khmer Rouge regime, Son Sen must bear some of the responsibility for the horrendous record of that regime. Whether or not he should be held personally to account for the gross human rights violations of the Khmer Rouge period is basically up to the Cambodian people to decide. To date anyway, it does not appear that the Cambodian people, at least as represented by the non-Khmer Rouge parties, are inclined to so regard Son Sen.

Successive Australian Governments have condemned the atrocities committed by the Pol Pot regime. The presence of two Khmer Rouge nominees on the Supreme National Council does not signify any change whatsoever to that Australian position, nor does it signify any Judgment about their personal culpability or otherwise for Khmer Rouge atrocities.

As to the question of whether Pol Pot or his most notorious associates should be allowed to stand in the election conducted under UN auspices, the Australian Government's position is that this is an issue which will have to be addressed in the peace settlement process-perhaps by way of agreement between the parties if not by some more formal disqualification provision. It is our present understanding, as I indicated in the Parliamentary Statement, that those whose past notoriety is greatest do not in fact intend to be candidates: certainly it can be assumed that if Pol Pot or any of his most notorious associates were to stand the International reaction, including from Australia, would be very severe.
Yours sincerely
GARETH EVANS

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469,274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Austudy: Family Allowance

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bushmead Rifle Range

That it remain in the hands of the Federal Government with a commitment to its ongoing use by the various rifle clubs of Western Australia.
Your Petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should heed the above.

that all State Governments, States Attorneys-General, most women's groups and the majority of men in Australia, including significant numbers of members of Parliament, are totally opposed to the importation and distribution of `X' and excessively violent `R'-rated video pornography in Australia;

That your petitions request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

I refer to questions that I have asked during Question Time in the Senate and through colleagues in the Estimates committee hearings concerning the distribution of staff, in particular political staff, in our embassies overseas and the network of Foreign Affairs officers in the Department, both in Canberra and overseas.

I am one senator who has long held the view that we do not apply sufficient resources to this Department. I continue to urge that additional resources are given to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade so that there are the personnel in Canberra and especially overseas to carry out the programs and to forward the proposals that are in Australia's best interests. In the six or seven minutes that I have had the annual report of the Australian War Memorial in my hand, I have not been able to establish whether or not it lays before the Senate the decision of the Australian War Memorial Council to introduce a charge for admission to the Australian War Memorial. Honourable senators will be aware of the fact that this announcement was made approximately two or three weeks ago by the Chairman of the Council. It was greeted with dismay, shock and horror by the veterans' community of Australia, who see the imposition of an admission fee, even to the exhibit areas of the Memorial, as being grossly inappropriate.

At the time that the announcement was made I said, on behalf of the Australian Democrats and, I believe, the majority of veterans in this country, that the introduction of such an admission fee was little short of crass commercialism of the worst kind. Since the announcement was made, the reaction of the veterans' community has built considerably around that resentment. Last week this was reinforced dramatically with the announcement that Mrs Moore, a volunteer of 15 years standing at the Memorial, had her services terminated, allegedly because she had spoken out against the introduction of the admission fee. She had pleaded with the Council to cancel some of the expensive social activities associated with the Memorial in an attempt to save money. In fact, she simply stated a position of dissent. She exercised her free right of expression, the consequence of which was that her services were removed after 15 years of voluntary service to the Memorial.

It is a sad irony that those who are commemorated in that War Memorial died in defence of that fundamental right of freedom of speech. It is not as though Mrs Moore's dissent had been expressed in an assertive or even in a public way prior to her dismissal. She made a very low key statement of her opinion about the decision of the Council, only to find herself dismissed after 15 years of voluntary service to the Memorial. Ironically, she was dismissed in the same week in which the Memorial advertised for volunteers. The Australian Democrats share with the community at large, but especially with the veterans' community, absolute disdain at the introduction of an admission fee, even to the exhibits associated with the Memorial. Further, we express our absolute dismay with the fact that somebody who has voluntarily served for 15 years was dismissed because she exercised her right of free speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak on the annual report of the Australian War Memorial. I regret that it was not available prior to tabling, and therefore it is very difficult to comment in any depth about it. Nevertheless, as Senator McLean said, there is a major issue facing the Australian War Memorial at the moment. I will spend the five minutes available to me in discussing that issue.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, I acknowledge that two Council members have died. One was Mr Reg Saunders MBE, who was the first Aboriginal Australian to be a commissioned officer in the Australian Army. He had served on the Council from July 1985, and I know that he will be missed. In addition, after the report went to the printers, we learnt of the death of the artist, Mr Clifton Pugh. He had also made a major contribution to the Memorial during his time on the Council and I express my regret at his passing.

However, the issue I wish to speak about is the decision taken by the War Memorial Council to charge for admission to the Memorial. In the last few days I have been concerned about the increasing tendency for the Memorial to be referred to as a museum. It is not a museum; it is a memorial. It would be sad if the Memorial Council started to think in this way and, indeed, it would be a very black day if the Council responsible for the Memorial were to use that language, as is happening around the country now.

The Opposition recognises the major efforts that the Council has made over the last few years to upgrade the Memorial. There have been enormous improvements. The Memorial is an important place of pilgrimage for all Australians. It is where one learns about the importance of peace because one sees the horrors of war. I recognise that there is a big demand for funds by the Memorial. It does need a lot of money, but it also gets a lot of donations and that should not be forgotten in this current debate. It is extremely important that the Memorial has access to funds for research, for assistance to the public, and for the education of the next generation of Australians. I recognise that there are lots of pressures on the Memorial Council to find the necessary funding to do all the jobs that it is faced with, and that is a dilemma for the Council.

The decision that was announced last month to charge for admission gives the Opposition some major concerns. We accept generally the principle of user pays. But in this case there are very real concerns that we are turning something which is a memorial to our dead into just another museum. This is even though the Memorial has chosen to distinguish between the galleries and the more sacred parts of the building.

I wrote to Dame Beryl Beaurepaire setting out the concerns and asking her some questions. I have now received a response which I do not find satisfactory in any shape or form. Dame Beryl has failed to come to grips with the access and equity issue. The Government has just released a report by the Office of Multicultural Affairs which goes into great detail about the ability of ethnic Australians to have access to the War Memorial. It looks as though the access and equity principles which may be extended to the ethnic members of this country are more important than for those who have actually fought for their country.

Nor would it appear that the access and equity questions are important when it comes to those who have donated items to the Memorial. Men and women who have lost mates or spouses, who have given their personal effects to the Memorial-those of us who have given letters or tapes to illustrate the social history of the wars through which we have lived-have been forgotten in the arrangements that have been made. Dame Beryl and her Australian War Memorial Council have failed to find a way to give access and equity to these people.

Finally, the Council has failed to get any sort of a guarantee from the Government that the funding will continue at the present levels and will be indexed accordingly following the introduction of the admission charges. It is clear that the War Memorial will end up being squeezed like a lemon. I urge the Memorial Council to think again. It has no guarantee of funding. It is not giving proper access to the men and women who have fought for this country or the people who have given to the Memorial.

I am also concerned about what has happened to Mrs Moore, the voluntary guide who has lost her position after many years of devoted service. This is not the way for the War Memorial Council and its committees to behave. I urge them most sincerely to give this whole matter fresh consideration. We in the Opposition are not satisfied with the answers that have been given by the Council.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The family allowance supplement (FAS) has made a significant difference to the living standards of a very large number of Australian families on low incomes for whom this program was designed. This evaluation report seeks to give an outline of the nature of the families which have either taken up or not taken up this payment. It provides an extremely valuable snapshot of the approach and response to this payment by families on low incomes.

The family allowance supplement was a crucial element in the Cass survey on social security. At that time a benchmark was established for the payment of FAS. The payments, expressed as a percentage of the married pension rate, were 15 per cent for children to the age of 12 and 20 per cent for those aged 13 to 15 years inclusive. This target was reached in 1989 after a December 1987 commencement date.

The characteristics of families for whom FAS has made such a lot of difference are summarised in the report that we are now considering. The report shows that FAS payments are being spent primarily on children; families have a high work force attachment and prefer to stay employed; the payment plays a vital role in helping families make ends meet, which is exactly what we had intended; it is used to pay for children's basic necessities such as clothing, food and school expenses; the majority of parents who were receiving FAS thought that their children were as well off as most children in Australia today.

The departmental records at the end of 1989 show that 61 per cent of FAS families received income of between $200 and $400 a week. It must have been at about that time that the means test was relaxed a little. FAS has had a significant effect on the level of net family income. Most families in this cohort rely on one income plus the FAS payment and there is a clear preference for the existing fortnightly cash payment. The payment is not influenced by perceptions of stigma. The high rate of take up probably reflects the FAS publicity campaigns, including regional office outreach programs and correspondence from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), rather than any structural change. It is thought that these campaigns contributed quite substantially to the increase in take up between its inception in 1987 and June 1988.

At June 1990-and these are the most recent figures given to us by this report-about 180,000 families were receiving FAS. The children of those families would probably number close to half a million. The main source of information about FAS comes, despite all of the efforts that we have made in terms of publicity, from friends and relatives, followed by the Department of Social Security and the media. The majority of people found information about FAS easy to get and reported no difficulties in applying for it.

As I said earlier, FAS has made an enormous difference to the well-being of very many Australian families. I think the Budget outlay in 1989-90 was in the vicinity of $514m, a very worthwhile expenditure. A comparison of eligible and noneligible families showed that, on the whole, the non-eligible groups were more likely to be in de facto relationships with fewer children and lower educational levels. However, almost all families receiving the payment have children of a very young age. The Government appreciated that the low, single income characteristic of families with young children made this extra payment absolutely essential for their well-being.

I wish to comment on the rural adjustment scheme, particularly as it relates to Western Australia. In commenting on this report, I emphasise that the rural adjustment scheme has been operating in its current form fundamentally since 1971-72. I wish to emphasise that many of the problems occurring in rural Australia, and rural Western Australia in particular, have been brought about, firstly, by the problems Australia has had internationally in the marketplace and, secondly, the economic policies adopted by the current Government.

The high interest rate regime, the lack of effort in reforming our transport industries, the waterfront and our general cost structures have been absolutely disastrous to the rural sector and to rural businesses. Since the Hawke Government has been in power, farm enterprises in Western Australia have dropped from 17,000 to 13,000 in what have been considered relatively good times. This drop has been a direct result of the lack of reform in the pipeline industries because rural production, as an export industry, depends very much on exporting from Australia at a competitive price. With the high interest rate regime that we have had, farmers and the rural businesses in the towns that support them have not had the opportunity to put any `fat' away so that they can ride through the present downturn or engineered recession.

I am concerned greatly that, according to the report in the press last week, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has placed emphasis on providing funds to take more people out of the industry. On the estimates which have been put forward in Western Australia by the Rural Adjustment and Finance Corporation of Western Australia, if the current situation continues, then another 3,000 to 4,000 farm enterprises or farming families will be leaving the industry in the next seven or eight years.

The time has come for the Government, through its economic policy, to address the problem. The rural adjustment scheme should be a facilitator primarily to assist people and businesses in rural industries to get over the rough spots so that they can continue. The tragedy is that we are now seeing people who are good operators and have an enormous knowledge and understanding of the industry being caught in this economic malaise which is forcing them out of existence. The flow-on impact in the rural towns, on the employees who work in agricultural industries-shearers and rouseabouts-and on people involved in the support industries, such as machinery dealers, will be quite disastrous. They are the people who are now moving out and joining the dole queues.

In terms of this report, it is time that the whole emphasis of rural adjustment was reconsidered. The real culprit for the problems being faced at present, including the necessity to pour in the dollar amounts talked about, is not the people working in the rural or support industries, whether they are efficient or not, but successive years of totally inappropriate economic policy which has pulled down people to their knees. That economic policy has been totally inappropriate to the requirements of those in the community who produce the real wealth.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
