TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering three separate pieces of legislation before the Senate today. The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill is a collection of corrections of sloppy drafting by the Government with regard to nine separate pieces of legislation. It includes amendments to two wheat industry Bills which the coalition in the other House tried to move during the passage of the original legislation. The Government has finally accepted the commonsense of these proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: The other Bills which are being considered today are the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill and the Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Bill. Both of these Bills are significant and important for the terms of trade between Australia and import countries and the meat and livestock industries. The purpose of these Bills is to give the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation power to implement and administer schemes to control the level of exports of Australian meat and livestock to particular markets where the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation board considers such arrangements would be in the industry's best interests.

The Australian Meat and Live-Stock Corporation already has the power to restrict the quantity of meat and livestock exported from Australia; to prohibit the export of meat and livestock to particular countries; and to administer meat quotas to a particular country where restrictions are, or in the opinion of the Corporation will be, imposed by either that country or Australia.

The experience with the live sheep trade to the Middle East, in which the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation experienced a deficiency, is the ability to impose controlling levels of exports. We have a situation in which the live sheep trade has been built up to approximately seven million sheep, half of which were going to Saudi Arabia. Trade had to be suspended when shipments of sheep to the Middle East were being rejected; the traders had been shipping older sheep and there was very little that the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation could do.

The Middle East nations, in particular Saudi Arabia, have specified quite clearly the age requirement of sheep. Since the suspension of live sheep exports to the region, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation has been rebuilding its trade. It has imposed two limitations on live sheep exports: first, limiting the shipment to one shipload a month; and, secondly, a far tighter specification with regard to the age of the sheep. It appears that the industry needs to rebuild the numbers on a more controlled basis and ensure that those live sheep meet the requirements of the marketplace. It is important that this industry is protected during the reconstruction of the trade.

With regard to the legislation under consideration, the coalition Liberal and National parties believe that what the Government is proposing goes too far. It gives the extension of a general export power, which is really only going to be utilised for one form of export-live sheep. In the past the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation has had those particular extensions as required and has managed them well. The coalition fails to recognise why the situation should need a different requirement.

It is the intention of the coalition to move during the committee stage amendments which we believe meet the requirements of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation and the live sheep export industry. They will bring some control to the market by restricting the power of the Corporation to live sheep only and restricting the ability to sell quotas to the live sheep industry.

There is no point in saying that the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation does not have certain powers to control the trade. There are, of course, better ways in which to control the trade. It is wrong to say that the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation does not have any powers. On the contrary, its powers include: cancellation of export licences; prohibiting the export of meat and livestock to certain countries; and bringing about more orderly trading.

I trust that the Government will accept the coalition's amendments. They will meet the current needs and avoid the potential trade and quota problems. If the amendments are not successful, the coalition will vote against the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst many aspects of the series of Bills before the Senate can be supported and in some cases are a relief to see, we should be very careful not to take for granted some of the information included in the second reading speeches incorporated by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate).

SPEECH.PARA: I turn first to a matter which will become apparent under the Australian Meat and Livestock (Quotas) Bill 1990. The justification for introducing this Bill was given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) in his second reading speech in the House of House of Representatives, where he said:
Because quota arrangements can, at times, result in windfall profits to exporters-
and there is no doubt that that is the case-
granted quota access, it has been decided to empower the AMLC to sell quota entitlement by auction . . .

I question that statement. That is true as it stands but, conversely, an existing exporter who fails to gain a quota at such an auction also has the potential to suffer a windfall loss. The loss would result from the existing provision of infrastructure and support systems which have been made at the exporter's expense. With such a statement in the Minister's speech, it is immediately apparent that there has not been sufficient consultation with the industry regarding these proposals.

During the period in which this Bill has been proposed, we have received several items of correspondence which make suggestions such as that the quota Bill receives intense opposition from exporters and traders, it creates a disincentive to trading meat and livestock from Australia, and the charging of quotas will result in lower producer returns. These sorts of reservations have been offered to us by people involved in the industry. We therefore intend to support the Opposition's amendments in this regard.

The Australian Democrats' amendment, which is to be offered in the committee stage as well, is directly connected with the export of live sheep. Our opposition to this practice is well known and documented. We will take every opportunity to highlight the lack of concern for animal welfare which participation in this trade illustrates. We are yet to be convinced that such trade is even to Australia's economic advantage. For example, considerable expenses are involved in moving live animals overseas and maintaining them in a saleable condition for several weeks at sea. I fail to see why exports of live sheep should be permitted at all when obviously the completion of the enterprises is so often subjected to international diplomatic manoeuvring, as we have seen recently. In such circumstances, our economic advantage would surely be best served by processing the sheep in Australia and not subjecting the sheep to the suffering that is guaranteed by the vagaries of international politics.

I turn now to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. We applaud and agree with many aspects of this Bill, which facilitates arrangements for the collection of levies from the pig and laying chicken industries for payment to the exotic animal diseases preparedness trust account. That is good and something which should be recognised as such.

We are also pleased to support the amendments to the Murray-Darling Basin Act 1983 which enables the Murray-Darling Ministerial Council to make decisions out of session. This council is charged with the direction and coordination of the Murray-Darling Basin initiative to combat land and water degradation and to develop sustainable resource use in the basin. We support the amendments, which should make the operation of this council more efficient.

In a similar vein concerning part 4 of this Bill, we shall be moving an amendment to clause 14 of the amendments to the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act 1987 so that the word `sustainable' is added to the clause and it will then read:
. . . conservation and sustainable resource management . . .

The committee that is being considered in this legislation is an independent selection committee. Its purpose is to nominate persons to the Minister for appointment to the Horticultural Research and Development Council. One would think that, in keeping with this Government's stated attitudes towards sustainable development, it is entirely appropriate that appointments to this corporation should be guided by expertise in sustainable resource use, a phrase which we were so pleased to see in the Murray-Darling Basin Act.

Other amendments which we will be moving to this Bill include alterations to the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987. This Act is a constant source of irritation and annoyance to people who believe that plant variety rights is a vehicle which will enable the manipulation of plant breeding and horticultural research by multinational companies. Those companies do not have the best interests of Australian agriculture at heart. In fact, we can see immediately that the development of hybrid plant types is dependent upon particular fertilisers, agricultural practices and pesticide usage. These plant types are often sold by the same companies which own plant variety rights. They lock primary producers into agricultural practices and expenses which would not necessarily occur if we were freer to pursue alternative agricultural methods. So we will be moving some amendments which are associated with the Plant Variety Rights Act.

By moving such amendments, we will attempt to ensure that, if the Plant Variety Rights Act is to operate, then at least it will operate with some degree of recognition of the traditional agricultural practices which have been able to bring Australian agriculture and its development of varieties to question other international practices and so often lead the world in what has developed in Australia. On some occasions in this legislation we are able to see room for congratulating the Government, on other occasions we will be supporting amendments moved by the Opposition, and on other occasions we see a very great need to move our own amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Bill 1990. In the short time allotted to me, I will briefly run over the reasons why there is even an attempt to have quotas.

SPEECH.PARA: As you probably know, Madam Acting Deputy President, the live sheep issue has provided lively debate for the last 18 months or so, particularly in the area of trade with the Middle East. In fact, it has been a lively debate for other reasons and Senator Bell slightly touched on some of those in his delivery, including whether live sheep should be transported at all.

In 1988-89 at least 7.1 million sheep were exported to the Middle East, though by the end of the 1989-90 financial year that figure had dropped to 4.4 million. That was due to the disruption in the Saudi Arabian trade as against the trade in the balance of the Middle East. Saudi Arabia imported around 1.25 million sheep in 1989-90, which was a drop of 60 per cent on the 3.1 million imported in the previous year. When Saudi Arabia dropped out Kuwait became the biggest trader, importing 1.37 million sheep. Of course, we have since lost Kuwait due to the Gulf crisis.

Since July of 1989 we have still had problems of rejection because of alleged diseases. The Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC) then halted shipments altogether. But that was a great mistake on the part of the Corporation. Instead of talking it through and trying to convince a high ranking Australian official, such as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) or the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), to become involved, it simply decided to cut out exports and starve the Middle East of live sheep. That short-sighted method certainly did not help by the time it came around to getting exports going again. So the AMLC does have a lot to answer for in this case. On 22 August 1989 the AMLC announced the resumption of trade for sheep up to three years of age, commonly known amongst the trade as the yellow taggers. In March of 1990, there was a further destruction of the trade because of disease.

It has been suggested that we should inoculate sheep against scabby mouth, which is the disease presenting the greatest problems. This disease, of course is, a passing phase, but I believe inoculation would work. I would not advocate having inoculation on the farms, because it is a live virus. But, with a 42-day retention period the sheep could spend 14 days on the feedlot, 14 days or thereabouts on the ship and then 14 days in quarantine when they get to Saudi or wherever they are going. Quarantining really has to be looked at, because the Saudis seem very hard to please. I believe that our sheep have always been presented pretty well and pretty clean, but the Saudis do not seem to understand this.

On 28 November it was reported that the Sheepmeat Council of Australia had accepted the amendments in this Bill, but the Council criticised the AMLC for not advising it of the proposed legislation. The Corporation went ahead with the Government and came up with this proposed legislation, but forgot to tell anyone else about it. Of course it recommended that quotas apply. In this case, the Saudis wanted only about 800,000 sheep a year, which is roughly 12 shipments of about 80,000 sheep.

We should now look at the provisions of these quota measures. Clause 6 provides that where a limit on exports has been or is to be imposed, the AMLC may grant a single quota allowing the export licence holder to make all exports, or two or more quotas allowing each export licence holder to make a specified amount of exports. The AMLC may grant a quota by auction, tender, private sale or allocation free of charge. A quota will have effect for a period, not exceeding two years, specified in the quota document. A quota will be subject to any conditions specified in the quota document.

The point is that quotas will interfere with a lot of current negotiations with the Middle East countries involved in the live sheep trade. The biggest problem I have in accepting quotas is that they could finish up in the hands of one exporter. Even if, say, three quotas are auctioned or placed by tender or private sale, under the Bill they are negotiable and could be bought by one exporter. If they finish up in the hands of one exporter, that exporter will dictate what he will pay to the farmer. Do not let anyone tell me any different. He will strike the price. There will be no intermediary to say whether or not it is a fair price. What is more, when quotas are sold, whatever price an exporter pays for a quota will be deducted from the amount paid to the farmer. Let no one tell me that is not correct, either. In every case where there is an intermediate stage in delivering agricultural goods overseas-this probably applies to other industries as well-the producer of those goods or livestock pays the price.

This measure will also penalise the operator whose infrastructure is already set up, who has already done the research. It will penalise those who have already carried out negotiations with the Middle East. A new quota holder can come along and make use of all that infrastructure, research and negotiations; he can simply pick it up and not bear any of the cost. In fact, that new quota holder might not even be welcomed in the Middle East. I understand that not all carriers and exporters of live sheep are welcomed over there.

The AMLC claims that it will be returning to the industry what payments it receives from the quota sales. The only thing it has forgotten to tell us is how it will be returned to the industry. How will it be done? Will it be on a per contract basis? If one farmer sells X number of live sheep to the exporter, will the Corporation reimburse that farmer? Remember that I have already told the Senate that the farmers will be paying a price in the lesser amount they will be getting for their stock to pay for the quota. Will that money be returned to them? No one has told us that. Will money be returned to the industry on a general basis; in other words, will funds be recycled like they are in the wheat industry, as I believe will occur with the wool industry levy? We do not know what will happen. Will it be wasted in general administration, in a way that we see again and again it is wasted in statutory bodies? My fears are that that is exactly what will happen.

Why does this Bill have to include meat? If live sheep exports are the problem, and we need to get quotas for that, why have in the Bill meat already slaughtered in Australia? I cannot see the reason. With the overproduction of sheep at present, the idea is to find more and more markets for our stock, either as live shipments or as meat. So why have a quota on meat as well? It is ridiculous. The Bill also designates the class of meat, the type of meat or whatever. I believe it is a scattergun approach to overcome one problem. It is putting in regulations that may or may not be needed in future, and I know that they are not needed at the moment. Why put them in if they might be needed only in years to come? I believe that the AMLC and its views on this should come back to the Parliament for scrutiny.

Our amendments have been spelled out by Senator Tambling, and I believe we should restrict the Bill to quotas on live sheep-if we have to have quotas at all. There should also be a sunset clause under which all these provisions will be brought back to the drawing board in three years time. This solution is a short-sighted way of going about the problem in the Middle East. It should have been sorted out in other ways before today, for the reasons I have already stated, and having a three-year sunset clause will provide a longer term approach. In three years time we can debate the matter again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In dealing with the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill 1990, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill 1990 and the Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Bill 1990, I will not go over the same ground as Senator Tambling and explain our position and the reasons for our amendments, but I would like to make some comments on the Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: I will begin by outlining how important the live sheep trade has been to Australia in recent years. It has already been mentioned that up to seven million sheep have been exported in recent years. I emphasise that up to five million sheep have come from Western Australia, which has been a very important part of the live sheep industry.

A point that I would like to pick up here-this point was mentioned by Senator Bell when he questioned having a live sheep export industry at all-is that to destroy the live sheep export industry would be economic and trade suicide. It is not in the best interests of our processing industry and our live sheep industry to talk about phasing some of it out. If we took that action, we would be opening up the live sheep trade to the dumping of subsidised European products, particularly beef, into those markets. We need to recognise that this trade is one of customer preference and has been for generations. When the hurdles in front of us now are overcome, I believe that will continue. In my view it is quite ludicrous for Australians to suggest that we should phase out this aspect of our industry.

The other point that has been so important about the live sheep trade is that it has been the base on which the whole price structure of the sheep flock has been determined for many years. As such, when we have a thriving live sheep trade, we find that this flows through; mutton prices are significantly better and there is a very notable increase in the returns to the producer on the commercial sale of wool producing sheep, including our fat lamb industry. As we all know, at the end of the day the producer has to make a profit, otherwise he goes out of business.

I believe that Australian marketing authorities, and the present Government in particular, have a real attitudinal problem with quotas. We are not putting enough emphasis on getting out and selling our product, marketing and sorting out the problems that we have. To highlight this situation, I cite as an example the very beneficial impact on the wool industry since the trip made by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), which related mainly to the wool industry.

The Government has had the opportunity for a number of years to play a much more positive role with the problems in the Middle East-not just in Saudi Arabia-with countries such as Libya, Iran, Egypt and others. Whether we like it or not, those countries deal not only on a government to government basis, but they also deal at the top of the hierarchy of their governments. They think it is an insult when we send over trade delegations or people who are not at the top echelon of our government at the time. While we will be moving amendments in the Committee state of the debate, I have great reservations about the attitudinal problems in Australia.

Another area in which we have been negligent in the live sheep industry is setting up trading arrangements with these countries for our various products. We should take imports from those countries to offset that trade. A classic example of this was the problem we had in the very early days when our sheep were rejected. I hope that those on the other side of the chamber are listening carefully to what I have to say. At that time, dumping action was taken against clinker being imported into this country. It had been purchased from the Saudi Arabian operation, which was owned by the royal family. They took that as a real insult. Of course, the dumping action was not sustained but it took some nine months to sort it out. In the meantime ships were tied off the Australian coast. If we are going to deal with these countries, we have to get our act sorted out as well as requesting them to get their act sorted out.

The whole issue of how we handle quotas also creates an enormous number of other problems. Senator Panizza has briefly touched on the issue of equity, in terms of how one gets the price back to the producer and the impact that will have. Unfortunately today we do not have sufficient time to go into all the aspects. Once one starts introducing restrictions or regulations and interfering with the ability of the market to operate, it creates situations which discriminate against some producers, some exporters, and favour others.

I spoke earlier about the problem we have with quotas in the wool industry and how to get equity between States in terms of their production and sales over the years and the restrictions that are now being put in place. As a Western Australian senator, I believe it will be very difficult for Western Australian producers to get equity for the contribution they have made to the industry over the years.

What will the criteria be for the selection of various exporters on this whole issue? Will the emphasis be put on whether or not they will be returning the best return to the producers? Will the emphasis be put on whether or not they have a particular type of ship in which the sheep will be freighted? What will the general arrangements be for the live sheep trade?

Another question on the quota arrangement is: will it favour some of the exporters or the shippers who operate out of the major ports-for example, Fremantle-and give them an advantage over those who have operated out of some of the coastal ports around the country?

When we start talking about quotas and we get involved in this type of restrictive activity-and I understand the problems that we have with that-it creates all sorts of distribution problems in terms of the practical application. From what I have seen and read on this matter, I do not believe that these problems have really been addressed. We can look at an idea on a piece of paper, write it down and decide that it is a good idea to have quotas, but it goes a lot further and deeper than that.

In my remaining minute, I will summarise what I said at the start. In my view, phasing out the live sheep trade can only be described as stupidity. It would be handing what have been traditional Australian markets to the subsidised products from the European Community. It would not benefit Australia, the producers or the exporters involved in the pipeline.

I re-emphasise the attitudinal problem we have in terms of marketing. One can look at a broad range of industries. It is very important that we become a lot more dynamic in our attitude to marketing, apply a little lateral thinking, and go to the highest level of government to sort out our problems. I think that the Libyan market could be sorted out without much difficulty. The rationale behind that does not make sense to me. I will reserve my comments on plant variety rights to the committee stage of the Bills when the amendments are moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak to this legislation, I note several things about it. Firstly, the legislation is specifically directed at the live sheep trade and not at any other aspect. Secondly, the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) is not involved in any other aspect of international trade and it already has powers through its licensing authority to regulate exports of live sheep, yet it is being given additional powers. Past rejections by Saudi Arabia of Australian live sheep, dating from July 1989, seem to form the basis of concern. Since then, there has been a lot of careful negotiation by Australian exporters to re-establish the trade. Frankly, this is now threatened by the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government did not consult with peak bodies involved in the trade, such as the Australian Livestock Exporters Association, about the legislation. The legislation gives an extension of general export power to the AMLC when it really only intends to use it in relation to sheep and is specifically, as I said, directed at trade with Saudi Arabia. Saudi Arabia is not proposing to introduce import quotas. It is interesting that there has been no meeting with the responsible Saudi Arabian Minister. The Government seems to have failed over a continuing period of time, that is, during the seven years it has been in power, to keep up the excellent relationship that was established with Saudi Arabia during the last coalition Government, particularly when Mr Anthony was the responsible Minister.

The legislation is contrary to the spirit of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. We have seen the Government preside over a decline in the share of export of sheep and sheep meat, largely to the benefit of New Zealand. It is important to note that this is another example of the poor relationship that now exists between this Government and Saudi Arabia which has resulted in a decline in our sheep trade.

I have recently been provided with a copy of correspondence between the Australian Livestock Exporters Association (ALEA), the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). Due to the guillotine being in place and the short time frame imposed upon this debate, I will refrain from reading the letters in full. I seek leave to table the letters.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The quotes that I propose to read from those letters show how poorly this legislation has been considered and it shows that most thinking and sensible people simply do not want it. The Director of the Australian Livestock Exporters Association, Mr R.G. Levy, wrote to the Chairman of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, Mr Austen, on 16 November 1990, and stated as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: ALEA totally reject the need for quota selling/tendering of allocation-
in the live sheep export trade with Saudi Arabia-

and seek an assurance from AMLC to take immediate steps to have this part of the legislation withdrawn. ALEA find the proposed legislation quite unnecessary, a perceived insult to our Saudi trading partners and an unacceptable intrusion into the commercial arena.
. . . will cause an even greater disruption to the trade that is occurring now.

Regardless of what any of us in Australia may think about the necessity of such legislation, the facts are that the Saudis see all the paperwork as evidence of a scheme aimed at forcing their market to pay $100 million p.a. extra for livesheep.
Mr Trivett urged Mr Austen-and I quote:
. . . in the strongest possible terms, to amend that request to exclude quota entitlement selling powers.
Mr Trivett wrote to Minister Kerin on 16 November 1990 and said that he was writing about the appalling breakdown in communications. He said-and again I quote:
We say appalling, because there is no other description appropriate, given the situation that we now all are confronted with.

The action taken to place this amending legislation before the Parliament was first signalled to this Association late on Monday 12th November and then by a party who was concerned to learn our views and position. Despite there being a mechanism for consultation that permits ALEA access to AMLC for such matters no such opportunity was provided to ALEA.

Surely this is the action of a government which is tired, a government which is simply no longer in command, a government which is not able to make the correct decisions for the benefit of this nation. We have been told that we are in a recession which this Government has engineered and induced. By the introduction of this legislation, we now seem to be attacking trade. In the words of the people who are on the commercial side of the operation, it is legislation which is designed to torpedo all their own efforts. Mr Trivett goes on to say:

Even a Minister who has enjoyed some regard for his ability is now seen to be letting the country down. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating cognately three Bills: the Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Bill, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill and the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill. Senator Tambling, supported by Senators Bishop, Panizza and Crane, has put the position for the Opposition. I talk on these Bills as they affect statutory marketing authorities. All of these Bills cover statutory marketing authorities which have come under a fairly severe attack during the last week-and I believe that they do need some defence in this Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Industry Commission (IC) report, which came out last Friday, treated statutory marketing authorities less than fairly. The report said that statutory marketing authorities were responsible for a transfer of 0.03 per cent to consumers from farmers. Those who compiled the report believe that that cost which will be added to the cost to the consumers will be around $550m. As we face tremendous problems in the horticultural industry, I believe that we need to address what that $550m represents. The authors of the report have arrived at this figure of $550m, or 0.03 per cent, by taking world parity pricing and then working out the difference between that and the cost of products in Australia.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I do not have to tell you of the hardships being experienced by people who produce horticultural products in rural Australia. As a resident of Kingaroy, you will be aware of the hardships being experienced by producers of horticultural produce in rural Australia and the agony that peanut producers and navy bean producers are experiencing, just to name a few. We are facing in this country a flood of imported products coming in under subsidies which are, to a large degree, although not all the time, being dumped or countervailed. Unless farmers have some defence against these products flooding into this country, then the figure of $2.134 billion will increase.

The IC, as it is now called, is taking no notice of that problem facing all Australians. That is why I say to Senator Cook that we are finding SPC Ltd in diabolical trouble. One of the reasons it is in trouble is that it is facing subsidised and dumped imported products coming into this nation. That is why some action has to be taken. The statutory marketing authorities are a defence against that dumping, but the IC has never recognised that. The IC is saying that it is costing Australia $550m to have statutory marketing authorities marketing and selling Australian products for the farmer.

I include in my contribution some figures that I received from the Department of the Parliamentary Library today. Between 1960 and 1990, the consumer price index (CPI) increased 637.6 per cent and total products, excluding agriculture, increased 755.1 per cent. The prices received at the farm gate only increased by 348.1 per cent. So, in real terms, the farmers are receiving half of what the normal wage earner has received in the last 30 years. The normal wage earner's wages and standard of living have increased by 637 per cent while the farmer has found that prices have only gone up by an amount that equals about half of that. That is why we cannot consider this issue just in automatic terms, as the Industry Commission has done.

The Industry Commission is suggesting that, if we just work on a completely flat playing field and import all our horticultural and rural products, we will save Australia $550m. That is very small thinking, and is not correct thinking, because it does not take into consideration the amount of imports that are flooding into this country. It does not take into consideration the increase of 348.1 per cent as against the 637 per cent CPI increase. So I say to the commissioners in the Industry Commission that they are not being realistic when they put reports out like this. I suggest to them that they go and walk around the marketplace and have a look at the imported products that are on the shelves of the supermarkets. To some extent, the report denigrates statutory marketing authorities, but certainly does not offer any other alternative. I do not see it of any use for a report to come out and say that statutory marketing authorities increase the cost of products.

The report also makes the point that farmers are forced into statutory marketing authorities by coercion-and that is not true. By a referendum at any time, by a majority decision, statutory marketing authorities can be abolished by the people they represent. Only two years ago in Queensland, the cotton farmers decided that a free market suited their needs best and they closed down the statutory marketing authority, and everything has gone very well for them. In fact, they are probably one of only a few of the primary industry groups that are showing increases at the moment. Of course, free markets are great on the way up. But on the way down sometimes one does need some assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Personalise your profits and socialise your losses, in other words.

—That is an inane comment from Senator Cook. Those sort of flippant remarks do not get him anywhere, particularly when he is now faced with 300 unionists looking down the barrel at losing their jobs. I would have thought that Senator Cook would have been able to come up with a better argument than that type of flippant remark. It is a throw-away line in the Australian Labor Party. It certainly does not get the rural producers and primary industry anywhere; and it certainly does not retain the jobs of the people working in the processing factories whom Senator Cook represents.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point that I believe the IC report was derelict in not bringing up is that, at present, three grocery chains control 70 per cent of the domestic grocery market in Australia. Those chains have tremendous market domination that can be used to suppress prices and increase costs to producers. Again, statutory marketing authorities are the only defence that rural and primary industry people do have against such market dominated forces. I agreed today to limit my contribution to 10 minutes. That time is now up and I thank Senator Tambling for allowing me the 10 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, without disrupting the debate, I seek to address the Senate for about two minutes. According to the shadow Minister, we are a minute or two ahead of schedule. I wish to touch briefly on the Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Bill 1990 and say that I find it absolutely without any merit at all. I can see absolutely no justification for it. The Bill is put to us because, as a result of difficulties in the Middle East, although there are present residual powers available to the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, it now requires particular and definitive powers.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for this is not completely clear to me. However, if it is suggested in some quaint, cute way that this will improve prices, it will be the first time that introducing discretionary quotas has improved the prices received by Australian growers for any product. One can provide figures subjectively on the basis of prices where quotas have been used, but fundamentally there is no economic or logical reason for arguing that because an authority is given a power to allocate quotas it will enhance one's prospects in a market or improve one's prices.

Is it being put to me that the power is required because there have been some-and I do not deny it-irresponsible shippers or growers who have done a disservice to themselves and the industry generally? If it is being put to me that quotas are required to control health considerations, let us understand that. However, quotas are not required to guarantee that. I have read but superficially the debate that has taken place in the media with a past Prime Minister of this great nation of ours who said that we could immunise against scabby mouth. It has been argued to the contrary, and I do not have sufficient knowledge to know which view is correct. I would have thought that it would be a monumental task. We all recognise that scabby mouth is particularly contagious. If it not detected beforehand, once a ship is at sea there is no prospect, in such a confined environment, of quarantining any section of the ship. That is why a great deal of care and concern ought to be taken from the outset.

Scabby mouth does not affect the flavour of the meat, but it does influence the aesthetic virtue of the stock. If I were buying a shipper to kill and put in the fridge and it was covered in scabby mouth, given my sensitivity in these things, I might be offended. However, this legislation will not change that. We can deal with the health problems by more diligence and vigilance by the appropriate authorities.

It is also fair-and I hope not unkind-to say that some shippers and growers have exported sheep which have been past the age limit set down by the Saudis. I do not know whether they thought they were all too clever and could slide a few in and the Saudis would not be bright enough to know the difference or whether they thought that not too much notice would be taken when the sheep reached their destination and it was just a nominal figure or gesture. Whatever the reason, they made a grave mistake.

It is not insensitive to say in this place that there are some politics going on in the Saudi royal family which have caused some problems with our shipments. But that is only part of it. One plunges oneself into the darkness of ignorance if one assumes that that is our only problem with our exports to the Middle East. This occurs at a crucial time because the market into Kuwait and other parts of the Middle East is closing down. I do not have the figures with me, but I believe the number has gone down from about seven million to two million: there has been a dramatic reduction. It is terribly important that our exports are accepted once they reach their destination. In many respects that will occur if there is proper diligence and supervision of the exporters and, in my view, this will not be enhanced by the prospect of quotas.

I now turn to prices. It is argued in Australia from time to time that when we compete with the rest of the world in a free trade situation we will somehow enhance our market if we have one muscle man competing with overseas buyers. I find it passing strange that that proposition is not put even by this Government in respect of iron ore, uranium, bauxite, coal, woodchips or natural gas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or alumina.

—Alumina and all the other products that give us the fragile wealth of which this nation is presently tottering on the edge. Nobody with any substantial respect argues that the iron ore companies have to come together collectively and do a deal with the Japanese to get a fair break. Nobody argues that the coal companies have to go together, holding hands, hoping desperately that they will not become unclasped in their negotiations with the Japanese. We do not require quotas for that; and nor do we need a statutory authority telling us who will sell what to whom and for how much. But, suddenly, when we deal with agriculture, things have to be different: irrespective of whether it is wool, wheat or sheep-whatever the cereal crop is-we suddenly need statutory authorities, arbitrary parliamentary control, quotas, restrictions, supervision: all those things that shackle the virility of the free market process and the free market system. Basically and philosophically, nobody outside the rural sector would argue with that. I do not know whether it is because of the insecurity that comes with this country's youth or some other inferiority complex that comes from spending too much time close to the land.
—It is experience. They know they have been hurt before.

—Experience is one of those vital elements of life that make one a better person for having had it. I have no doubt that good experience ought to be built on and we ought to learn how to get our share of any market without cobbling together some socialist legislation for the purpose of having growers and producers hiding behind some statutory body. I would not want to draw any comparisons, but let us look at what has happened to the Australian Wool Corporation recently. The price of wool was up at 870c and the world was barking. The growers were over the moon. If we think the Corporation is a genius and that is the way we should go-that is the sort of structure we need-we have not learnt much in the last 12 months. I hope that we will allow free trade within the normal sensible parameters, taking health matters into consideration.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

This is a cognate debate which is limited in time and I will be brief in my reply. On behalf of the Government, I thank Senators Tambling, Bell, Panizza, Crane, Bishop, Boswell and, latterly, Senator Crichton-Browne for their contributions and the comments they made. —We are in government and it is our right to be right and our right to be wrong, and may our record judge us in the end, as it will inevitably.

—Yes, and so far we have had a pretty good success rate in getting re-elected. That is enough of the minor political skirmishing. Back to the Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bell from the Australian Democrats indicated that he will move an amendment, which the Government will not accept because it would have the effect of closing off some options in this trade. The Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation has set rigorous conditions for livestock exports. Unfortunately, many Middle Eastern markets prefer live sheep to mutton and any move to limit live sheep exports would not help in the current circumstances. The Government will not accept that amendment. Senator Tambling from the coalition will move in the committee stage some other amendments which the Government will accept.

I do not wish to reply to much in the debate, except to say that when I came into the chamber Senator Bishop was making some uncomplimentary remarks about the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation. That body is appointed on the recommendation of its peer group; it is not appointed by political patronage. I should indicate for the record that Senator Boswell, the Leader of the National Party of Australia in this chamber, nodded his head in the affirmative when I made my first observation on peer group approval for the appointment of this body. The Australia Meat and Live-stock Corporation represents producers and exporters of livestock and meat. It also comprises people with industrial relations, promotional and finance capability, and it is a body which is respected in the wider sweep of the rural community. Against those credentials, criticisms have been put by meat traders, such as Mr Trippett, who represent the middleman, that is, not the producers but the agents who sell the livestock. I think this is a classic case of a vested interest speaking for itself against a group composed of the wider community representing the public interest. In those circumstances, I do not think the record should go unanswered on the basis of this chamber now rejecting the criticisms made by Senator Bishop.

My final comment is about a remark made by Senator Boswell. Of course, the Industry Commission (IC) makes reports and does so fearlessly according to its lights and to the need to examine rationally within an economic framework what is to be done. Those reports advise the Government and are not binding upon it. They provide an opportunity to promote informed and intelligent debate on those issues. That is not to say that the Government accepts them or every element of them; nonetheless, it is a contribution to the debate process. Any implication that the Government would necessarily pick up all the recommendations of an IC report should be seen in that light. I thank honourable senators for their contributions to this debate. Although in opposition to the Government, most of the remarks have been helpful. I commend the Bills to the chamber.

We have, we hope, set an agenda for debate about health which we trust will involve the community very extensively. In days of rising health costs and restrictions on the amount of money that governments wish to spend on health, there is no doubt that a very significant community debate has to take place about the allocation of resources and the setting of priorities in respect of those resources. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 10, page 5, insert the following Part:
``Part 2a-AMENDMENT OF THE DISABILITY SERVICES ACT 1986
Principal Act
``10a. In this Part, `Principal Act' means the Disability Services Act 1986.
Interpretation

``10b. Section 7 of the principal Act is amended in the definition of `accommodation support services' by adding at the end `and, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, includes attendant care services, namely, services to persons with disabilities to assist them with personal administration, transport, mobility, transfers, personal hygiene, bathing, grooming, dressing, eating and drinking, and similar personal activities'.''.
After Note 1 at the end of the Bill insert the following Note:
``1a. No. 129, 1986, as amended. For previous amendments, see Nos. 80 and 99, 1988.''.

The Disability Services Act 1986 contains within part 2, section 9 (2) the kinds of services that may be funded under that Act. Nine service types are currently included in definitions of those service types. They are included in section 7 of that part of the Act. The service type `accommodation support services' is defined there as follows:
Services to assist persons with disabilities to develop or maintain suitable residential arrangements in the community.

Whilst this definition encompasses everything that we would currently support in that area, the definition of `residential arrangements' has been at times misunderstood. The amendment proposed today will assist in clarifying the intentions of that service type.

In 1986, the nursing homes and hostels review heard from many people with physical disabilities who were permanent residents of nursing homes and who expressed a clear preference to live back in the community. The only barrier to this appeared to be the absence of community based care or modified accommodation. The Government responded by establishing the national attendant care scheme in the 1986-87 Budget. Eligible applicants for the national attendant care scheme are aged between 16 and 64 years, are permanent residents of a nursing home or have used respite care in a nursing home for more than 130 days in the past year, or occupy a nursing home classified bed in a public hospital with little chance of returning home without support.

The scheme fosters maximum self-direction via the consumer who selects the service agency that will employ his or her personal care attendants and directs those attendants on a day to day basis. I do not know that any of this is relevant, but I conclude by saying that attendant care provides services that assist persons with a disability with their personal administration, transport, mobility, with their personal hygiene, dressing, eating, drinking, and with every aspect of their lives. This is no more or less than that which was envisaged in the definition within the Act for `accommodation support services'. This similarity was obviously realised by the review working party. However, it is now clear that some groups still mistakenly believe that the attendant care model of services is not possible under the Act and have narrowly interpreted accommodation support as congregate care grouped homes. While this is patently incorrect, this Government does not wish possible confusion to discourage people with disabilities from being supported to live in the community, in the setting they choose, and in the way that they choose.
The amendment moved here today will make it clear to all concerned that the Government is genuinely interested in individuals and in individual solutions to their difficulties.

The amendments to the Disability Services Act (DSA) which I have circulated were contained in a private member's Bill presented to the House of Representatives in November by the shadow Minister for community services and aged care, Mr Ray Braithwaite. A year before that, in November 1989, Mr Braithwaite laid before the Parliament a draft Bill suggesting amendments to the Disability Services Act 1986. In his introductory speech, he said that that draft Bill was essentially a discussion paper and that he hoped it would provoke comments, suggestions and discussions from people with disability, their parents, relatives, carers, governments- in fact all those concerned with, and for, people with disability. The response to this initiative was gratifying. Mr Braithwaite received over 400 telephone calls and submissions, and he addressed interest groups in all the mainland States.

The amendments to the Disability Services Act, which I have circulated, were contained in a private member's Bill presented to the House of Representatives in November. Following that presentation and those consultations, Mr Braithwaite presented further papers and further discussion ensued. We worked together on developing these amendments so that they would be in line with and address some of the concerns that have been expressed around the community.

The tabling in Parliament of principles, objectives and guidelines, which is one of the issues addressed in Mr Braithwaite's amendments and in the amendments I am circulating here, should be subjected to and available for amendment, if necessary, and approval. In the second reading speech of Senator Grimes, the then Minister for Community Services, during the debate on the Disability Services Act in 1986, he said that these principles, objectives and guidelines would be tabled. Four years later, not one of them has been laid before the Parliament.

Bringing these principles, objectives and guidelines before the Parliament will provide greater assurance of adequate opportunity for proper debate on such vital matters which could alter the thrust of the Act or its implementation. Using the affirmative resolution mechanism of requiring Parliament to approve rather than disallow, as is the case with most regulations tabled, provides an opportunity for proper consultation, public participation, input, criticism and awareness; and then debate, amendment if necessary, and final approval by the Parliament.

The Australian Democrats supported this mechanism in connection with the charter and agreement on residents' rights and responsibilities in nursing homes and hostels. I had hoped that we would have their support on this amendment, but it seems from my discussions with them that that will not be the case. We have seen, as I am sure the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, will acknowledge, cooperation between all parties on those residents' rights and agreements. I believe we could have seen similar cooperation if we had been able to bring those principles, objectives and guidelines under the Disability Services Act into this Parliament for discussion and debate. Had that been done, we believe that this would have had the effect of curtailing any proliferation by the Department of Community Services and Health of supposed guidelines which have now created uncertainty, rigidity and confusion.

These amendments provide for three new service types to be provided under section 9 of the Act: firstly, attendant care services, signalled by Mr Braithwaite for some considerable time-and we have now got the Government responding to one of its Budget initiatives at this very late hour. The other two are staff training services and vocational training services. The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) said that attendant care services will be brought under the legislative coverage of the DSA. Although we have been waiting for this service type, the Minister did not act until we pushed him with these amendments.

The coalition is committed to the improvement of the quality of life for all Australians who have a disability, and we believe that, wherever possible, this should be achieved by providing services which are within the mainstream of the community. However, we are opposed to ideology overtaking commonsense, and hence we support the provision of specialist services where such services are obviously appropriate to the needs and free choice of the client group and valued both by that client group and the community at large.

We make no apology for the fact that we support the continuation of the best of existing nursing homes and hostels, sheltered workshops and activity therapy centres, where such services provide the best practicable lifestyle for particular clients. We all know that a number of services were in need of changing, and the sector itself has admitted that. But, as I said, we still support the view that there is a purpose and a place for choice, flexibility and diversity. We believe that there should be a happy coexistence of the old and new services beyond 1992, but we acknowledge that, as more and more new services are established and more and more younger clients with different educational experiences, backgrounds, aspirations and expectations seek services, the old services will naturally contract.

Extension of the transition date of 1992 has become necessary, especially as the Department appears to be admitting that the deadline of 1992 cannot be met. Even the reviews of services cannot be completed by then. The Minister admitted last month that the number of people with a disability employed in the Public Service had decreased. This was an issue I addressed in the Estimates committee, based not on a huge amount of research but on moving around the community, going to sheltered workshops and talking to the service providers about the problems they were facing in getting their clients into open employment. The constant comment that came to me in those consultations was that the service providers were having great difficulty in placing people with disabilities in the Government sector. That came to me over and over again. That view was vindicated when the Minister said that the Public Service was not in fact holding up its end.

If the Government cannot employ people with disabilities and set the example-and we have had an answer today to one of our questions on the Estimates which shows just how many departments are not meeting that requirement, and it is an exorbitant number; over 70 per cent of departments have not increased the number of people with disabilities in their employ-then those people with disabilities will be left in a vacuum, forced there by the haste with which this legislation is being implemented and trapped because the government sector and perhaps private enterprise are not able to meet the demands of that program.

We propose to extend the deadline to 1995, with the intention that we would still keep pressure on those service providers who can change their services to enable people with a disability to achieve their total fulfilment under the Act. Should the Minister insist that transition must be complete by 1992, then he will be closing, not opening, the door of opportunity offered under the Act to many people with disabilities. Extending the transition date will give some security to parents of children attending sheltered workshops and to those whose children are at special schools.

These amendments provide some degree of predictability in financial assistance and some degree of restriction as to terms and conditions which may be imposed by the Minister in approving the making of a grant of financial assistance. If these amendments are carried, it will no longer be possible for the Department-with or without the sanction of the Minister-to press upon recipients of grants unilateral, harsh or unwarranted terms and conditions.

Finally, we have proposed an amendment providing for an appeals procedure in order that the decisions of the Minister and his Department may be reviewed. Such a mechanism is included in most other legislation of a similar nature, and we believe that its non-inclusion in the Disability Services Act was an oversight on the part of the then Minister. These amendments are concerned with accountability-part of what the Democrats call `keeping the bastards honest'-and we believe that the adjustments proposed are the amendments that were evidently in the mind of the then Minister, Senator Grimes.

It is a sad reflection on the Government that, despite its knowledge of our intentions for some 12 months, it has not moved to consult with service providers or consumer groups or to amend the Act to provide both departmental and Ministerial accountability. Nor has it addressed the question of whether sufficient funding is available to keep pace with the demand for services.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendments moved by Senator Patterson. The reality is that what the Government is proposing will not be effective. Any strategy that treats doctors as the residual pawns in a bureaucratic game will perhaps not provoke the wrath of the doctors but will be ignored by them-which is even worse from the Government's point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: What is needed is a charter that is acceptable both to the people who run the nursing homes and to the residents, and these amendments do that. Bureaucrats and politicians have no concept of what occurs around the death bed. There is no place at the death bed for politicians, bureaucrats and lawyers; it is for the families and their medical attendants. We need within this Bill something that allows for that charter.

As an example of that, I am reminded of something that occurred in my clinical experience. A friend of mine was asked to give a patient who was in extremis an intravenous injection. The bureaucratic requirement was that the doctor, not a nurse, had to give the injection. The patient was gasping his last and the doctor gave the injection. As he did so, the patient expired. The doctor was horrified at what had occurred and, as he started to leave, the relatives asked to see him. All sorts of thoughts crossed his mind. Was he covered by medical defence? How was he going to explain it? The senior relative came forward and said, `Doctor, that took a lot of courage'. The point I am making is that what occurs in real life needs to be accommodated, not something that shall be dictated by the bureaucracy.

A private hospital in Queensland once determined that it would decide which person gave anaesthesia in the hospital, much along the lines that the Government is now trying to make a determination in relation to nursing homes. The hospital set a standard which was opposed by the Australian Medical Association. So there was a confrontation between the hospital and the Medical Association. The head of the hospital said, `If you wish, we will convert the hospital into a motel because we are the ones that decide the standards that will be proposed'. It is the same situation here. It does not matter. We cannot control what type of standard will be determined and the amendment proposed by Senator Patterson will give credence to that. I support that amendment.

These particular amendments have been the subject of extensive consultation-I understand not with Senator Harradine or the other Independents-but certainly between the Australian Democrats, the Opposition and the Government. On the whole they are to do with tidying up the agreement and serve to clarify the intention of the agreement. I will just enumerate some of those matters.

Clause 4 of the agreement sets out the services to be provided by the proprietor to the resident. These services include care and accommodation. It is proposed that subclause 4.1 be amended to further define `care' as `nursing home care'. Clause 4 also makes provision for a schedule which sets out any services, facilities and goods that the proprietor and resident agree shall be provided which are in addition to those the proprietor is required to provide. It is proposed that clause 4.2 be amended to delete reference to a schedule and instead state that a document shall be attached to the agreement which lists the services, facilities and goods ordered by the resident. It is also proposed that subclause 17 (a) (iii) be amended in line with and as a consequence of this amendment to clause 4.2.

Clause 5, for example, sets out the conditions under which the proprietor can levy extra charges. It is proposed that a new subclause 5.4 be included which states that any extra services, facilities and goods must be freely requested by the resident without any undue influence from the proprietor. Such extra services might include daily newspapers or hairdressing. Subclause 12.5 sets out the right of the resident to obtain any legal, financial or administrative advice and support that he or she requires. It is proposed that this subclause be amended to add that this advice and support is to be at the resident's own cost. This reflects the existing situation and clarifies that the proprietor does not have to bear this cost.

Clause 13 sets out the obligations of the resident, including an obligation to respect the rights of a proprietor, staff and other residents within the nursing home. It is proposed that this clause be amended to provide that a resident fulfil these obligations as far as they are capable to ensure that those residents who may be confused or not responsible for their actions are not in breach of the agreement.

Clause 21.3 sets out the grounds on which a proprietor may end the agreement, including where the nursing home is no longer able to provide suitable accommodation and care for the resident because of the resident's assessed long term needs. It is proposed that the time in which the resident is to supply the assessment report of her or his practitioner be extended from five to seven days. Subclause 21.3 (g) sets out the circumstances under which the agreement may be ended where a resident has been absent from the nursing home for seven days. It is proposed that this subclause be amended so that the agreement cannot be ended where the resident and proprietor have agreed upon a fee to maintain the resident's place in the nursing home during her or his absence.

There are other minor drafting changes made to the agreement which tighten up the wording of provisions, but I believe they will not result in any change to the meaning or effect of the provisions; hence, in this bundle of provisions, I believe there is good ground for the agreement that has been reached in consultation prior to the presentation to the Committee.

Eleven of the amendments that we have moved have been agreed to by the Australian Democrats in the hours of discussions we have had outside the chamber. Some of these amendments are minor and reflect drafting corrections, but a few deserve explanation. Nowhere in the document was there any mention of the requirement for residents to be informed of the rules of the nursing home prior to signing the agreement. It seemed to us absolutely necessary for residents to be informed of the rules of the nursing home before entering into agreement. We have amended the agreement accordingly.

A couple of the amendments modify the agreement so that impossible demands are not placed upon the proprietor. For example, clause 6, as it is tabled, is almost incomprehensible because of drafting and grammatical errors. The proposed amendment clearly imposes fair and reasonable obligations. As the clause now stands the proprietor is expected to guarantee that a resident will not be assaulted by a fellow resident or by a visitor. In all practicality, when running a nursing home one cannot monitor every moment of the day who will be in the nursing home. Even though all precautions might be taken, a resident may be subjected to some sort of assault, whether it be verbal or physical, without the proprietor being able to have any sort of protection for that individual resident, even though he or she might do all within his or her power to do so.

The absolute guarantee of privacy in clause 7 is unreasonable. Our amendment incorporates the concept of privacy as it is expressed in the international covenant on civil and personal rights. The amendment seeks to clarify where rights and obligations lie and to remedy drafting defects in the clause as tabled.

Our amendment to clause 11 makes it more reasonable. It is unrealistic to require the proprietor to provide secure storage for valuable possessions of a resident without any indemnity from the resident. The draftsman probably had in mind small personal items. But personal effects do not refer just to jewellery and small things such as television sets; they include all chattels. Some constraint needs to built in to ensure that the personal effects of residents are stored subject, as we have amended in the clause, to the space constraints of the nursing home. It is entirely impractical for a resident to expect that his or her personal effects will be stored in the nursing home, if the nursing home does not have the facility to do so. Our amendment brings that into a more realistic form.

We are aware that residents come to regard their rooms and their beds as their personal space and territory and that they should not be moved at the whim of a proprietor. But we also recognise the practicalities of running a nursing home and are of the opinion that it may be necessary to move a resident to allow for minor or major building or repair activities in the home. Hence our amendment to clause 15.

The other amendments attempt to clarify the intentions of the agreement. I will not take up the time of the Committee by going any further into our reasoning behind these as we have discussed them ad nauseam in the meetings outside. Had the business of the Government been better organised, we would not be debating this very important legislation under the guillotine and I would have been able to explain the amendments fully. Given that we are operating under a time constraint, I ask honourable senators to support the amendments that I have moved.
