In this debate we have a most delicate situation: balancing the rights of residents already in a nursing home, those who have worked to provide the facility and those who are actually working in the facility against the rights of those who may want to enter a nursing home but who cannot conform with the rules of that home. All of us who have debated this issue have put a lot of effort and, in some ways, a lot of heartache into thinking this through.

One of the arguments behind the Opposition moving this amendment is the belief that people in a nursing home-in many cases, they have chosen to go to that nursing home because it is run by a church or a group to which they belong that expresses their values, their morals and their beliefs-should be able to spend the rest of their days sharing their time with people who hold the same values.

Over 35 years ago Baptist women-I say this for the benefit of women in the chamber-had the foresight to demand that their church buy land so that a nursing home could be established at North Balwyn. That was in the days when aged care was not on the agenda. Those women had planned ahead. They put enormous efforts into raising money for that property.

I know that not only has there been government support for the capital development of nursing homes but also there has been an enormous effort by volunteers in all of those organisations to establish aged care places of a high standard which would hold their own anywhere in the world. I can say that with some authority, having visited aged care centres in many countries. Many people in some of those fine institutions have dedicated their lives to raising money. Many people who have voluntarily given their time to the residents hope to move into nursing homes themselves. Because of government subsidies, somehow there is to be intervention by the Government in terms of the rules that will be applied.

Some time ago-I think it was 1985 or 1986-I was quite horrified to read a news report of a nursing home, either in the southern part of New South Wales or the northern part of Victoria, in which an elderly couple who wanted to be in a room on their own to talk were in breach of the rules of that nursing home. At the time I expressed my concern. The rules of a nursing home might be ridiculous, but it is worse when the rules of a nursing home are not known before the people go into it. I was surprised that the Government did not have an amendment, which we now have, which indicated that people should know the rules of a nursing home before they sign an agreement.

I guess the only concern I would have is the situation where somebody may be required to go into a nursing home, or where the choice is limited in a regional area, but I think that that, if it occurs at all, would be very rare. It would be a greater infringement of rights if people had to live with others who did not share their philosophical or ethical values. As I said before, it is a very delicate balance of rights. Many of us have thought long and hard about this and anguished over it, and after all that we have come up with this particular amendment which I support and which the coalition supports.

One of the other things our amendment does is extend the limited religious exemption provided for in the Government's amendment. Our amendment includes charitable or similar voluntary nursing homes, because there are some nursing homes which are not necessarily religious in that sense but which in fact have expressed moral values because of the charters of their organisations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the amendment concerning clause 3, rules of the nursing home, because it believes that the sorts of sentiments which have been expressed by Senator Patterson are to be found within the clause as it is presently drafted, particularly in 3 (1) (b). Senator Patterson's amendment would read:

SPEECH.PARA: The proprietor and the resident agree to abide by the rules of the nursing home except insofar as the rules are inconsistent with this Agreement or the Charter set out in Schedule 1 or the standards for nursing home care published from time to time by the Minister.
Frankly, I cannot see a lot of difference between that and the present agreement, which in 3.1 (b) reads:

to the extent that the rules of the nursing home are consistent with this Agreement and with the Charter set out in Schedule 1 and with the standards for nursing home care published from time to time by the Minister, the proprietor and the resident will abide by them;
It is precisely the same, with just a slight reversal in the sequence of the phrases and clauses in the sentence.

I believe that we are on common ground in trying to acknowledge a situation where the proprietor and the resident agree to abide by those rules which are consistent with this particular scheme but which of course can elaborate on or go beyond-but not in an inconsistent way-the provision of the charter and the agreement as we have discussed them in committee this evening.

I believe it is important that that supplementary character of the nursing home rules be acknowledged. I think Senator Patterson is correct to say that there are many instances where people will find the bare bones of the agreement do not really, despite their great merit, make entry into a particular nursing home the attractive proposition which it should be for them, embraced within a philosophy of care which accords with a belief and the values which they almost certainly would have held for decades as they reach the frailer aged years of their lives.

I believe that there is a place, certainly, for nursing home rules. I believe that the agreement as drafted makes exactly the same provision as Senator Patterson seeks to achieve, though perhaps in a more legalistic way and not quite as positively as her amendment, but I do not believe there is any reason to depart from the language that has been adopted.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Patterson's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (19) Clause 10, omit subclause 10.2, substitute the following subclause:

``10.2 have access to medical, health and social services of her/his choice, but a medical practitioner shall not have the right to treat the resident in the nursing home if the medical practitioner will not agree to observe the ethical principles of the proprietor in the exercise of the practitioner's profession within the nursing home;''.

As we have seen from the various newspaper reports, in the last two weeks there has been a great deal of debate and discussion on subclause 10.2. The newspaper reports have constantly referred to the fact that residents should have the right to the doctor of their choice. Our amendment does not deny a resident the right to the doctor of his or her choice. However, it does specify that that doctor must observe the ethical principles of a proprietor when practising in a nursing home.

A number of my colleagues wish to address this matter, so for the sake of not delaying the Committee any longer I will leave it up to them to go into more detail about the reasons for our moving this amendment. As I said before, we asked the Democrats to consider our amendments and I regret that they will not be able to support this amendment either. I call on my colleagues to put the case. This is one of the most complicated matters that have gone through the chamber for a long while. Senator Herron, who is a new senator, made some comments on the charter. I am sure he will add to them when he speaks to this amendment and will support me in moving it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier tonight I made a speech which, in my inexperience, I thought at the time was supportive of the amendments that Senator Patterson was moving. I wish to add a few comments to those which were out of place at that time. The point I was making was that it does not matter which law we pass or what the bureaucracy determines; if a patient does not wish to accede to the requirements of a nursing home that patient will need to find somewhere else to go. Alternatively, if a patient insists on a particular doctor and that doctor does not conform to the requirements of the nursing home, what will happen in the real world is this: when a doctor who is known not to conform to the nursing home's requirements rings up to get a bed for the admission of the patient, the doctor will find that there are no beds available. It is as simple as that. That is what occurs in the real world. So no matter what the bureaucrats and the politicians think, in reality, the nursing home will determine the requirements of the patient to accede to the morality of the nursing home or hospital.

SPEECH.PARA: I referred earlier to an incident that occurred years ago when a hospital decided that the doctors would need to conform to its requirements in relation to anaesthesia. It decided that doctors would not be admitted unless they had specialist qualifications in that regard. The Australian Medical Association opposed the decision of the hospital. The Mother Superior of the hospital confronted the Australian Medical Association and said, `If you wish, we will turn it into a motel'. Honourable senators can appreciate what happened-the doctors backed down, they accepted the requirements of that hospital for a high standard of anaesthesia. It is one of the leading private hospitals in Australia.

Senator Patterson's amendment will achieve what occurs in real life. It does not matter what the strict requirements are in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill, in the sense that the amendments are being moved by the Government. As I mentioned earlier, any strategy that uses clinicians as the end point in a bureaucratic game will be ignored by the clinicians because in the real world the doctors treating the patients in the nursing home, in consultation with those patients and their families, will determine the management.

We think it is only logical that the amendment proposed by Senator Patterson, which recognises the real world, should be adopted by the Government. I support that amendment because it satisfies the requirements of the church nursing homes. In reality, they are the ones providing the service; they are the ones that have asked for this requirement. For the life of me, I do not understand why the Government does not agree to that requirement. After all, the Bill imposes a restriction on church nursing homes, which they will not follow in any case, because it is contrary to their principles. The Opposition amendment satisfies those requirements and it would be satisfactory to the churches which control the nursing homes. I support the amendment as proposed by Senator Patterson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I, too, wish to support my colleagues on the amendment to subclause 10.2 of clause 10. As Senator Herron put very well, this issue is a matter of commonsense. For the life of me, I cannot understand why the Government has not accepted the advice of the Australian Catholic bishops who have very strongly opposed the draconian attempts by the Government to override the rights of nursing home proprietors who have firm religious beliefs and also high principles in their philosophies of care. These philosophies must not be compromised. Practices of over-sedation, euthanasia, treatment of a patient against his or her wish and breaches of a patient's rights must be opposed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) has told representatives from the Australian Catholic Bishops Conference that the amendments they seek would negate residents' rights to a doctor of their choice. On the other hand, a doctor who ignores the moral principles and religious conscience of a particular nursing home against the operator's wishes would create a larger problem than the one the Minister is concerned about.

I note in the Minister's reply to the Catholic bishops that he promised that an independent committee, which would include church representatives, may be set up to review the operation of the agreement and charter at a later time. I must say that that is not acceptable. Earlier today we heard from the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), who is at the table, that the regulations that were put down in, I think, 1986-Senator Patterson was making inquiries about this-still have not been enforced. If that is an indication of how things move in that particular ministry, a committee which has been promised by Mr Staples, I am sure, would take some time to review the matter. In any event, I do not believe that the people involved should have to wait in the faint hope that a committee may come up-I repeat, may come up-with an acceptable argument at a later date. It is not good enough. If we are going to enact legislation, we should do it properly.

I believe that Senator Patterson and her advisers should be congratulated for the amount of work they have put into looking at this very complex piece of legislation and amendments, and congratulations should go also to the Australian Democrats and the Government for the work that has been done. I am pleased to see that a compromise has been reached in a number of areas. As I said earlier-and as Senator Herron has said-I cannot understand why the Government will not accept this amendment that we are putting with the full support of not only the Catholic bishops and the religious organisations but also other religiously run institutions. It is the only argument the Government has, at the moment anyway, with all the agreements.

There has never been any question about the tremendously high standard of care that has been afforded by Catholic nursing homes and, in fact, other religious nursing homes. I think it is very important that we do not jeopardise that care, and anything that will jeopardise that care must be vigorously opposed. I have certainly received a lot of representations, as I guess other senators have, from concerned Catholic bishops-and I think they are genuine concerns. Any agreement that allows a doctor to act in a way that is contrary to the basic moral and Christian principles of Catholic religious orders or any other religious order that operates nursing homes must be opposed. The fact that the President of the Australian Catholic Bishops Conference, Archbishop Clancy, took the trouble to contact the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and had conversations with him in itself shows just how strongly they feel about the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —That doesn't make it right.

—In conclusion, I say to Senator Zakharov that I would like to thank the Archbishop of Hobart, Archbishop D'Arcy, for contacting me about this matter, too; he brought his concerns to me personally. I ask the Democrats to think again about this particular matter. It has been dealt with separately. It is a matter that is causing a lot of concern to the majority of religiously run institutions in Australia and-as I said earlier, as Senator Herron has said and as Senator Patterson has alluded to-I cannot understand for the life of me why the Government will not accept this minor amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to state very briefly the Australian Democrats' concerns on this issue. What we believe has been happening for the last three years is, in effect, the original wording as the Government proposed it, and there does not seem to have been the outcry from the community that is now being suggested that there will be if the legislation passes in its present form. The Democrats wish strongly to support the rights of nursing home residents. These, I must stress, are not additional rights; these are the same rights that anyone in the community would enjoy-the right for them to choose their own doctor. This doctor may be a general practitioner who has treated their family for 10, 20, or 30 years, and now, because they move into a particular nursing home, they are going to be asked to reassess their trust and their faith in this particular person and perhaps to change to somebody else who they may not know and, at that particular time in life, they may be very reluctant to trust that person.

SPEECH.PARA: If I can dwell on a couple of points raised by Senator Calvert, I feel very strongly that these amendments are draconian attempts to limit and restrict the rights of the residents. After all, the documents we are dealing with tonight-the charter, the agreement-are aimed at protecting the rights of people in nursing homes and hostels in their latter years of life as they would enjoy those rights in the community. The Australian Democrats believe it is an affront to the nursing homes themselves to suggest that somehow all these incredible things will happen if they let these doctors in. It is an affront to the doctors themselves to suggest that there are doctors in the community who are not ethical, who are somehow not practising legitimately in some way and who will-Senator Patterson alluded to a number of media reports-do all sorts of unethical things if they are allowed to continue to treat people they may have been treating for many years. While we dwell on the number of people who have contacted us on this issue, we have also had representation from the bishops-a group which I must stress was not involved in the original negotiations because it does not run nursing homes. We have not heard from those who do; that is, the various orders of Catholic sisters who run Catholic nursing homes. I have not heard from individual Catholics who are concerned about these measures.

Again, the question should not be why some proprietors should seek to remove those doctors but why these rights should not apply to residents of nursing homes. I want to stress at this point that Catholic nursing homes are held in extremely high regard in the community. Indeed, they are held in such high regard that many people seeking to be residents of them are not Catholic. I believe all those individuals should have the right to choose their own doctor; therefore the Australian Democrats will not support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was hoping to hear from the Minister--
—You brought on this clause, not me. I would be interested to hear your views.

—The Minister shall. I am pleased to hear that the Minister is interested in my views and I will be interested to see whether he agrees that in this area Mr Staples has created unnecessary conflict. I say that quite deliberately. Senator Lees said she had not heard from the nursing orders. The first I heard about this issue was the publicity in the Australian when that great nursing home order, the Little Sisters of the Poor, commented about the proposed nursing home agreement. Frankly, that was the first time I have heard the Little Sisters of the Poor come out publicly on anything. It is a dedicated order which has been in existence for decades, serving the aged people of Australia and elsewhere. The response of Mr Staples was to attempt to belittle the Little Sisters of the Poor. I heard Mr Staples say, `Well, we hope to get some charity into this debate.' Who is he to suggest that the Little Sisters of the Poor, the sisters of charity, do not have charity? The order worked on the smell of an oily rag years before any money was made available from government sources for the support of aged people in the homes run by the order.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we ought to get a few things straight. What right has the Government to come in now and attempt to impose on them a clause which is going to violate their consciences if they sign?

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the patients' considerations and the patients' values?

—Senator Zakharov says, `What about the patients?'. Does she not think the Little Sisters of the Poor, the Sisters of Charity and all of the rest of them have had that in the forefront of their minds all of the time?
—No, I don't.

—Senator Zakharov says that she does not consider that these dedicated orders of women have had at heart the conscientious interests of the people that they have served for years and years. I do not know where we are going if she does not believe that, because I believe that everybody else around this chamber would say that they have.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that not only have they had the rights of residents in nursing homes foremost in their minds, but they have also established a very high standard of care in accordance with the philosophies of care which are well recognised. It is that philosophy of care which they see should not be compromised. In this area, it could be compromised unless this amendment by the Opposition, or something similar, is adopted.

Senator Lees suggested that the amendment is an affront to the medical profession, to the doctors themselves. I refer Senator Lees to the Medical Journal of Australia of 20 June 1988, volume 148, in which there is an article by Helga Kuhse and Peter Singer, notorious from the Centre for Human Bioethics, Monash University. They reported on a questionnaire which was sent to 2,000 Victorian doctors selected at random. It was a survey of attitudes and practices of doctors in Victoria with respect to requests for active help in dying from patients who are suffering from a terminal or incurable disease. Here we are talking about the rights of nursing home proprietors, including of orders of nuns, to protect the aged within their care. Of those doctors, 896 returned completed questionnaires. I quote from the article:
The survey indicates that a clear majority of those who responded to the questionnaire support active voluntary euthanasia and that many doctors have provided active help in dying.

Is it not appropriate that the philosophy of those involved in health care who preserve the rights of the aged in the nursing homes they run should not be compromised? Should they not have the right to prevent a doctor who has an attitude of supporting euthanasia from attending to persons in homes for the aged-nursing homes? I would have thought they should; that is facing facts. It is an interesting thing. It may be said, `There are laws which would protect people', but there are not laws that will give people full protection from the onslaught of euthanasia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about their own wish?

—Senator Zakharov says, `What if it is their wish?' We could go into that, but the guillotine is going to chop our heads right off in a minute. The life of this debate is going to cease very shortly, but I would like to go into that matter. It seems to me, since Senator Zakharov has asked that question, that with the Government's amendment which says that the proprietor, with the consent of the resident, may require any medical practitioner chosen by the resident to agree to respect, et cetera, we get to a situation where many of these people in nursing homes need the protection of those who run the homes-protection from a medical practitioner who may have an attitude such as was described in the Medical Journal of Australia article. It is very interesting to see that this article was written by Helga Kuhse and Peter Singer.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said before, although there are certain laws-and we will no doubt go into those later-the fact is that there is not any protection for an aged person in a nursing home against a doctor who has that sort of attitude. The only protection, of course, is that of the people who care for the aged people in those nursing homes. We have Senator Tate's own Government paying $450,000 of taxpayers' money to the Centre for Human Bioethics. But these medical research funds were used not for the purpose of undertaking medical research but for the purpose of developing a philosophy for destructive experiments on human embryos. At the other end of life we had the Government's own money going to Helga Kuhse to assist in developing the occasional paper for the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.
So we have some people in the health bureaucracy who would not mind euthanasia-it would get rid of a lot of monetary problems. That is why this amendment is important--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is outrageous.

—Is Senator Zakharov suggesting that Singer and Kuhse have not received this money? That is why this is important. Although I have not spoken to them individually, I have a letter from the Catholic bishops. There is no doubt that they see this as very, very serious indeed. I received a letter from them today-presumably everybody else has received it-dated 17 December 1990. The final part of the letter from the Australian Catholic Bishops Conference states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Catholic Bishops have already decided to advise Catholic nursing homes in their dioceses and religious institutes conducting nursing homes not to sign the Agreement if clause 10.2 of the Agreement is not amended to enable Catholic religious bodies to sign the Agreement in good conscience.

That is a very serious statement. I would be interested to know what the response of the Government is on that. It does not apply only to Catholic organisations; it applies to a whole number of organisations. I have letters-which, no doubt, other senators have-on this matter. The Committee is about to make a very important and serious decision and I hope that Senator Patterson's amendment is carried.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was stimulated to rise by the statement of Senator Lees and Senator Zakharov's interjection-I am sure, with Senator Tate's concurrence-that the nursing home patients abrogate their right to a doctor of choice when they go into a nursing home.
—Who says that?
—Senator Lees. Senator Zakharov said, `What about the rights of the patient?'. Correct, Senator Zakharov?
—That is right.

—Senator Tate supports the principle of Medicare. All patients who are admitted to a public hospital in this country abrogate their right to a doctor of their choice. So I am happy to go ahead tomorrow and announce that the Government has changed its mind in relation to Medicare, that henceforth, under Medicare, patients will have the right to a doctor of choice. That is the logical conclusion because the Government will not accept the Opposition's amendment. If the Government opposes our amendment, it is insisting that patients shall have the doctor of choice in nursing homes and therefore, as a corollary, in public hospitals.
—They are not patients in nursing homes; they are residents.

—Residents-call them what you will. They are people, Senator Tate. They are human beings, like the Minister and I. They are ill. As Senator Harradine said, they need loving care. But I assure the Minister that they will not get it from government. They will get it from the people who provide the care in the nursing homes.

SPEECH.PARA: Long before government came in, nursing homes were traditionally run by religious orders and religious bodies. What is happening now? Government is saying, `No, you don't know enough about it. We are going to determine how you shall look after those people. We are going to determine who will look after you. We are going to determine how that care will be given and if you do not do what we say, we will cut the funds off'. The Government is saying, `If you don't follow our dictates, we will cut the funds off'.

What is the answer, Senator Tate? Residents though they might be, the Government is insisting that they have the doctor of choice. What about residents in the hospices? What about the residents in places like Mount Olivet? They do not have the doctor of their choice. They have a nursing home attached.

It is frequently said that the number of patients admitted to hospitals in Australia is proportionally far greater than in any other country. The reason is that, because of our decentralisation, many patients who should be in nursing homes are actually in hospitals, particularly country hospitals. The people who come from Tasmania, Victoria and New South Wales would not be aware, as they never travel around the backblocks of Queensland or Western Australia, that many of those hospitals cater for nursing home-type residents. One may call them residents, patients or whatever one will, but they are people; they are citizens of this country and they demand and expect not only a high standard of physical care but an extra dimension which is given by the churches and the religious orders.

So the Government should not think for one moment that those nursing homes do not have the rights and responsibilities of the individual at the forefront of their objectives; of course they do. It is a responsibility of government to provide for those people and it is the very people who are in need of that care who demand even more compassion from government than those who can afford to go to nursing homes of their own choice. So there is a responsibility which cannot be abrogated, and it is a responsibility that we all have. Senator Tate can play with the semantics of whether they are residents or patients or whatever, but they are people-human beings in nursing homes-and the people who provide that service have a right to determine the quality of care and the philosophy behind it.

Again I return to Senator Calvert's query, `Why does the Government not agree to the amendment? It solves the problem'. If the Government did, it would not have this battle on its hands. The passage of this Bill is not going to stop that battle; I can assure the Government of that. The bishops are not going to go away and I can tell Senator Tate that when we are well and truly under the ground, the churches and the nursing homes will continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not going to agree.

—They are not going to agree, as Senator Calvert says. So by all means, do not accept the amendment, but Senator Tate and I both know that this is not going to be the end of it. I support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It has never been my contention-I am sure it is not that of the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples)-that governments have a monopoly on the provision of tender loving care for those frail aged who find themselves spending their last days in the nursing homes of this country. It is also important to say that that tender loving care is not a monopoly of the church either. There have been great religious orders founded by extraordinary women-one thinks of the Blue Sisters and so on. Florence Nightingale was regarded as a heretic, an atheist, and a loose woman because she dared to bathe men. The nursing tradition in Australia has as much, if not more, for which to pay tribute to Florence Nightingale as to any of the great teaching orders, but I would not want to say one is better than the other.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that there are many-both those of a secular frame of mind and those motivated by religious ideals-who devote themselves to the care of the aged in our nursing homes in Australia. I believe that they all deserve our commendation and praise because they undertake one of those civilising influences in our society which are so important.

Senator Harradine said that in many ways this debate is unnecessary. I agree with him: in many ways it is. I have in my hand Gazetted Standards for Nursing Home Care, gazetted on 10 November, 1987, by Neal Blewett, Minister of State for Community Services and Health. This document, which has regulated the provision of nursing home care in Australia for the last three or so years, contains the following clause:
Standards to be observed in the provision of nursing home care in approved nursing homes:
1. The nursing home will ensure that each resident receives appropriate medical care by a medical practitioner of his/her choice when needed.

That particular standard of nursing care, gazetted three years ago in November 1987, has governed the operation of nursing homes in Australia, and as I understand it nursing homes run by the Catholic Church have acquitted themselves well in respect of that particular provision. In other words, there has been 100 per cent compliance.

I imagine, though I have not had access to the materials but I am assured by officers, that the Little Sisters of the Poor have had no difficulty in the last three years in complying with that provision. I repeat:
The nursing home will ensure that each resident receives appropriate medical care by a medical practitioner of his/her choice when needed.

The phraseology has not proved a barrier to the provision, within the Catholic nursing home system, all other nursing home systems or individual nursing homes not part of a system, of a range of medical care which is permitted within the nursing home in a way which obviously has caused no great difficulty. The bishops have decided to make this an issue in relation to euthanasia.

Let us remember the debate. The question of sexual activity in nursing homes was first raised. It was in relation to comments by the Sister Superior of the Little Sisters of the Poor in that regard that probably caught Senator Harradine's attention. A delegation led by Bishop Kelly came to my office twice. The next time the members of the delegation came to see me-about 10 days later-they moved off the sexual agenda entirely and exclusively and added euthanasia. It is in relation to euthanasia that they have decided to take their stand at this time, as Senator Calvert so perceptively said. No doubt it will change next week.

I will make it absolutely clear that the Government is utterly opposed to the practice of euthanasia, forbidden as it is by all jurisdictions throughout Australia. I am referring to passive and active euthanasia, whether it is not putting the respirator on when it is required or putting the needle in too early. Senator Herron would know that, whilst euthanasia is something to be abhorred as a criminal activity, nevertheless there will be occasions when a compassionate Catholic doctor, in conjunction with the nurse or the sister in charge of the little room where the elderly person is painfully eking out the last hours of life, will hasten that person's death in a gentle and compassionate way. Senator Herron will know that that is a fact. Surely when we are talking about how things actually happen in our society, no-one would say that that does not happen in the best of nursing homes. Thank God that some of the sisters running the Catholic nursing homes are more compassionate than the bishops in this regard.

It is important to refute some of the matters that Senator Harradine raised. He said that the health bureaucracy would have an interest in this and that it would help them to get rid of a lot of a problems, particularly of a monetary kind. I regard, as an absolutely despicable assertion about those who are concerned with the various bureaucracies of health care throughout Australia, this suggestion of a motive for their bringing forward this clause in this amendment. The health bureaucrats of this country have not determined on a course of getting rid of elderly patients in nursing homes in order to secure some sort of monetary benefit. I find that an extraordinary type of assertion.

Senator Harradine also said, `Well, if this goes through, there will be no protection for those who might be at the mercy of some doctor who wants to practise euthanasia in the nursing home'. I am sure that Senator Herron could once again confirm the fact that, when a doctor does his rounds, particularly in that situation where there might be a temptation to give a little more of an injection than is normal, he would be doing it in conjunction with and under the supervision of an ever vigilant sister on the ward. There is no way in which the doctor just goes in and performs that sort of activity solo.

I come to the question of whose rights are at stake because, in the provision as it would be amended if the Government's amendment is carried later this evening, we do not have an authoritarian or totalitarian approach by the Government. But we are not going to stand by and allow an authoritarian or totalitarian approach by a proprietor either. I commend Mr Staples for moving to this position. The first draft of the agreement reads:
The resident has the right and shall . . . have access to medical, health and social services of his/her choice.

Mr Staples, having listened to the argument and having tried to understand and be sympathetic to the concerns of the nursing homes, as expressed on their behalf by the Catholic bishops, as it is said, offered this amendment:
The resident has the right and shall . . .
have access to medical, health and social services of his/her choice.
. . . Where the proprietor of a nursing home is a religious body the proprietor may-
. . . bring to the attention of a resident and of any medical practitioner seeking to practice in the nursing home the doctrines, tenets, beliefs and teachings of the religious body; and

. . . with the consent of the resident, require any medical practitioner chosen by the resident to agree to respect and observe the philosophy of the religious body when practising his/her profession within the nursing home.

In many ways that is somewhat redundant because, if we were talking about euthanasia, clearly the philosophy of the religious body would be entirely in harmony with criminal law anyway. Quite explicitly, Mr Staples has said and recognised that there is a balance which perhaps was not given enough weight initially. In our multicultural, pluralist society where an organisation-in this case a religious body-runs a nursing home, some weight has to be given to the factor of a particular ethos, a particular set of values animating the dedication of that group to the running of a nursing home. There is a recognition of that distinctive ethos of the particular nursing home, but it cannot completely submerge, swamp, overwhelm and suffocate-perhaps I should not use that term in this context-the interests of the resident.

Mr Staples has said that where there is a meeting of minds, as surely there will be, between the resident and the proprietor of the nursing home, the particular nursing home can direct the medical practitioner not to practise medicine within the nursing home unless he agrees to respect and observe the philosophy of the religious body concerned. There is a difficult task there but it is an attempt to recognise that we live in a multicultural, pluralist society and that some nursing homes will have their own religious ethos. But that has to be combined with, in a cooperative and collaborative way, the rights of the resident.

Mr Staples has hit a good balance in the clause that he has offered. He has gone further than that. He said that if in any jurisdiction in Australia there was a move by any parliament which was successful in trying to modify the criminal law and provide for euthanasia, he would have written a provision into the agreement to make sure that that was taken account of. I believe that this was put up to the bishops a week or so ago, but they said that that was not good enough.

Mr Staples has gone further again and said that, given the three years experience that we have had of the successful operation of the outcome standards for Australian nursing homes, which include the provisions in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, which I have mentioned, perhaps we should see how this agreement works and, if there are any problems, a joint committee with church representation would be able to review the operation of the agreement.

We should pay some deference to Senator Herron, who has had more experience I guess than anybody else in this chamber in dealing with the elderly and with those in nursing homes and so on. The way that these things work on the ground will be somewhat different from what we might think they are in the abstract or based on the written terms of this agreement, however fairly devised they may be. I think they will also function differently from what the bishops might think is the ultimate standard of attainment of a particular moral principle.

I believe that within the nursing homes-Catholic and otherwise-there will be an ability to work within the particular clause that Mr Staples has now offered as a very reasonable approach to trying to balance--

The nursing home will ensure that each resident receives appropriate medical care by a medical practitioner of his/her choice when needed.

Having quoted that, he said that the nursing homes run by the nuns have managed to stay within that in the last three years so why can't they do it now? That is what he said. He did not quote what he should have quoted. It states:
The guidelines provide a summary of key issues, followed by a more detailed description of information to look for with respect to each standard.
This appears in the introduction. It then says:
It is stressed that this document provides guidelines, not hard and fast rules, and as such standards monitoring staff are expected to use their judgment in the application of the guidelines.

There is a difference-and the Minister knows it-between those loose guidelines, which are not hard and fast rules, and this measure. Not only is it a hard and fast rule, but unless the nursing homes sign the agreement, they are not entitled to receive Commonwealth money. There is a vast difference between that matter and this one. Why try to pull the wool over the eyes of the chamber? Why did the Minister not quote from this document? I have received correspondence from Mary's Grange and it does not want this provision in the agreement. That is the fact of the situation. Of course, Mary's Grange, since it has been mentioned, will want to see that its residents have the doctor of their choice. But I am sure Mary's Grange wants to have a situation where it can exclude such practices as over-sedation, euthanasia, treatment against patients' wishes, and other breaches of patients rights which are morally unacceptable and against the background of their philosophy of care.

I will not say any more because time has almost expired. But it is important to get a few things on the record. Senator Tate seems to infer that this issue started on the aspect of sexual matters. I have the documents which came from the Australian Catholic bishops in September. Those documents go over a wide range of issues. They date back to September. TALK.START.PARA: —Like hell!

(2) Subclause 8.1, omit ``by those in, and coming into the nursing home'' and omit ``to'' after ``an individual and''.
(3) Subclause 8.2, after ``maintain personal decision'', insert ``making''.

(4) Subclause 8.3, after ``nursing home staff and other residents'', insert ``. This subclause is not breached by any action by a religious body operating a nursing home that is taken in good faith in accordance with the doctrines, tenets, beliefs or teachings of the religion of that religious body, being an action taken in good faith in order to avoid injury to the religious susceptibilities of adherents of that religion.''.

(5) Subclause 9.3, after ``birth or other status.'', insert ``This subclause is not breached by an action by a religious body operating a nursing home that is taken in good faith in accordance with the doctrines, tenets, beliefs or teachings of the religion of that religious body, being an action taken in good faith in order to avoid injury to the religious susceptibilities of adherents of that religion.''.

(a) bring to the attention of the resident and of any medical practitioner seeking to practice in the nursing home the doctrines, tenets, beliefs and teachings of the religious body; and

(b) with the consent of the resident, require any medical practitioner chosen by the resident to agree to respect and observe the philosophy of the religious body when practising her/his profession within the nursing home;''.

In respect of amendment No. 6, we have already had a very full debate on the matters of concern which led to that particular amendment being drafted. Given the fact that we have only four minutes left on this debate, I believe I need not rehearse those arguments.

Amendments Nos. 4 and 5 cover those clauses which were designed to deal with the claims made by the Catholic bishops that nursing homes may have forced upon them the free choice of their residents to indulge in certain forms of sexual behaviour which are incompatible with the doctrines, tenets, beliefs or teachings of the religious body which ran the particular institution.

That particular matter has been dealt with, I understand, to the satisfaction of the Catholic bishops in that a political precedent was drawn upon, which is found in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act of 1986 where senators will recall that, in relation to discrimination, the notion of `discrimination' was defined in a way which excluded:

any distinction, exclusion or preference . . . in connection with employment as a member of the staff of an institution that is conducted in accordance with the doctrines, tenets, beliefs or teachings of a particular religion or creed, being a distinction, exclusion or preference made in good faith in order to avoid injury to the religious susceptibilities of adherents of that religion or that creed.

I believe that that particular recognition by the Parliament-and I believe it was probably inserted actually in debate in this particular chamber-indicates the proper political grounding for the amendment which is offered in clauses 4 and 5 before the Committee at the moment. I commend those particular amendments to the Committee.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 10 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister's department or any agency for which the Minister is responsible entered into any contracts with Gary Morgan's company, Roy Morgan Research Centre, since 1975; if so, for each contract since 1975:
(a) was there a specific contract; if so, what were the specifications of the contract and was it altered after it was entered into; if not, why not;
(b) what was the fee;
(c) was the contract put out to tender; if so, why was Roy Morgan Research Centre chosen; if not, why not, and why was the Centre chosen;
(d) was the Centre specifically asked by the Minister's department or agency to supply a copy of the questionnaire;
(e) did the Centre supply a copy of the full questionnaire used to conduct the survey; if so, please provide a copy of the full questionnaire;

(f) if a part only of the questionnaire was supplied, was the Minister's department or agency aware of the exact nature of the full questionnaire; if not, why not, and what safeguards were taken to ensure there was no conflict of interest or subject bias;
(g) were there any questions asked by the Centre which were not included in the report supplied by the Centre; if so, what were they;
(h) please provide a copy of the Centre's report;

(i) if, for whatever reason, the Minister's department or agency will not provide a copy of the report, please provide an outline of its contents and an explanation as to why the Minister's department or agency refuses to provide a copy;

(j) was the Centre specifically asked by the Minister's department or agency to provide a computer printout of the survey; if so, did the Centre provide an interpretation of the survey results; if not, what special skills and qualifications does the Minister's department or agency have in the interpretation of attitudinal survey data and please provide an outline of how the survey data was interpreted;
(k) how were the survey results used by the Minister's department or agency; and
(l) did the proposal to commission the survey emanate from within the Minister's department or agency or from within the Minister's office or another department or agency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Available Departmental records indicate that three contracts have been awarded to the Roy Morgan Research Centre since 1975. These were a two-part evaluation of the Family Allowance Supplement (FAS) survey in June and October/November 1989; an assessment of Family Allowance advertising in September 1989; and a contract for the conduct of surveys and analysis to determine the social impact of the Child Support Scheme in November 1990.
Evaluation of FAS Survey
(a) Yes. The contract was the standard form contract for consultancy services. It conformed to the Department of Administrative Services guidelines.
There were no alterations to the specifications after the contract was entered into.

(c) Yes. Roy Morgan Research Centre was selected for this contract on the usual basis of competitive submissions from a short list of consultants whose specialised expertise and suitability for the assignment are known to my department or the Office of Government Information and Advertising.
(d) Yes.
(e) Yes. Questionnaires will be made available to the honourable senator after the report has been tabled in Parliament.
(f) Full questionnaires were provided.
(g) No.

(h) The contract to the Roy Morgan Research Centre was only one of several major tasks undertaken as part of the Family Allowance Supplement (FAS) evaluation. The final report for that evaluation is to be tabled in Parliament in the near future. A copy of the report will be sent to the honourable senator after it has been tabled.
(i) Not applicable.
(j) A complete set of computer printouts is not held by the Department. However, specific tabulations are held.
Yes, the Roy Morgan Research Centre provided an interpretation of the data. It also provided a report on each of the stages of the FAS survey.
(k) The survey results have been used extensively in the final report of the evaluation of the FAS program. They have also been used for administrative and policy purposes.
(l) The proposal to commission the survey emanated from my Department.
Assessment of Family Allowance Advertising
(a) No. There was no contract as the assignment was small and the research company was appointed by OGIA on behalf of my Department.
(c) No. The assignment was put out to selective proposals from two consultants because it was a small but urgent one.
(d) Yes.
(e) Yes. The questionnaire is included in the report.

(f) No. We were not provided with the full questionnaire because my Department's questions were included in a ``shared cost'' omnibus survey in which a number of clients combined questions for one interview. Each client's questions are confidential to that client and we would not expect to be informed of them.

We rely on the integrity of the consultant and their membership of the European Society for Opinion and Market Research which binds them to a code of professional behaviour ensuring such conflicts do not arise.
(g) Yes. See previous response. My department was not aware of all questions or provided with a response.
(h) A copy of the report will be forwarded to the honourable senator.
(i) Not applicable.
(j) No. The Department received computer tabulations for all surveys as specified in Clause 4 of the standard contract. The Roy Morgan Research Centre provided an interpretation of the data.
(k) The survey results have been used to measure the effectiveness of the family payment advertising campaign.
(l) Yes. The proposal to commission the survey emanated from my Department.
Evaluation of Child Support Scheme
(a) Yes. The contract was based on the Department's standard form contract for consultancy services and conforms to Department of Administrative Services guidelines.
There were no alterations to the specifications after the contract was entered into.

(c) Yes. Proposals were sought from eleven prospective tenderers of which six submitted tenders. The tender from the Roy Morgan Research Centre was selected on the basis of a comprehensive assessment of the relative merits of the tenders. The assessment was based on criteria including:
whether the tender met the data and analysis requirements specified in the research brief;
value for money;
the qualifications and experience of staff nominated to work directly on the project; and
the resources of consultant(s) to carry out the proposed work program.
(d) Not applicable-no questionnaire exists as yet.
(e), (f) &(g) Not applicable.
(h) No report exists as yet. A copy of the Centre's report can be forwarded when the evaluation is complete.
(i), (j) &(k) Not applicable.
(l) The proposal to commission the survey emanated from a Government decision to undertake external research to evaluate Stage 2 of the Child Support Scheme.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Iran: Executions of Homosexual Men and Women

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 11 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports of public executions of lesbians and gay men in Iran, and, in particular, a report from the British Embassy in Tehran in March 1990, confirming the authenticity of such reports.
(2) Is Australia's Embassy in Iran monitoring the situation.

(3) If the Minister is aware of these atrocities, has the Australian Government formally expressed its outrage to the Iranian authorities; if not, and in the light of Australia's commitment to human rights, could the Minister investigate further these reports and take appropriate action.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Government is aware of allegations of public executions of homosexual men and women in Iran. Under the religious laws of Iran, homosexuality is classified as a crime. Cases that come to the knowledge of the Iranian authorities, even of consenting adults, have been met in some instances with severe punishment.

During a crack-down on prostitution in Tehran in 1989, several people described as prostitutes were executed; some of these people may have been homosexuals. According to the Australian Embassy in Tehran, those executed may also have been implicated in illicit drug dealing. Executions of homosexuals for attacks on minors are reported periodically. There does not appear, however, to be evidence that the Iranian authorities are going out of their way to hunt out homosexuals, nor evidence that there is a concerted anti-homosexual campaign.

Australia's High Commission in London has been informed that the British Embassy in Tehran (which was not open in March 1990), has not prepared a report on the execution of homosexuals in Iran. There have been a number of reports on the human rights situation in Iran which deal inter alia with the question of executions, including reports by the UN Commission on Human Rights' Special Representative on Iran: the first of these reports was released in March 1990, and the most recent report was released on 6 November 1990.
(2) Yes.

(3) The Australian Government is firmly opposed to capital punishment in all circumstances. The Government's concern over the excessive use of the death penalty in Iran has been firmly and frequently conveyed to the Iranian authorities, both in the multilateral and bilateral context. The Government will continue to press the Government of Iran to adhere to international human rights standards, and to cease this cruel and inhumane form of punishment.
